member.name: T:Hca.Common.Builder.ObjectBuilder
member.summary: Provides functionality to create and initialize objects from an XML representation.
member.remarks:
The XML schema that uses is defined in the file ObjectBuilder.xsd. This file is embedded within the common assembly. The resource name for this file is Hca.Common.Builder.EmbedFile.ObjectBuilder.xsd. The target namespace URI is http://hcaschema.hca.corpad.net/Common/Builder/2.0/ObjectBuilder.xsd.
The following table shows the attributes that are associated with each element. Some attributes are required and these are shown without any decoration around the attribute name. Some attributes are optional and these are shown with brackets around the attribute name. Default values are shown in parenthesis, e.g. [attributeName](defaultValue).
ObjectBuilder Elements and Attributes
Element Attributes Usage
object
[type](System.String) The type of name of the object.
[value]
The value of the object. This string must be able to be parsed by the specified type.
Used to define primitive or complex type objects. If type is not specified, then the defaults to the type of the member being assigned to, or the base type of the collection being assigned to. If cannot discover a type by any of these methods, then the type of is assumed. The element can contain the following elements: object, property, propertyList, propertyDictionary, and ctorArg. The element also allows mixed content meaning that text or CDATA character can be placed inside the element and this will be assumed to be equivalent in meaning to the value attribute.
It is an error to both set the value attribute and define mixed content.
An object element with a child object element is considered an array.
ctorArg
[type](System.String) The type of name of the object.
[value]
The value of the object. This string must be able to be parsed by the specified type.
A complex object may optionally contain one or more ctorArg element. The ctorArg elements represent the type and order of the parameters of the constructor that should be invoked to initialize the object. If no ctorArg elements appear, will attempt to find a default (zero-parameter) constructor.
property
name The name of the property.
[type] The type name of the object.
[value] The value of the object.
Represents a property on the object. Properties behave similarly to objects except that they are named, and can only appear within an object element. If the type is not specified, the framework will attempt to determine the type based on the property being assigned to. If the framework cannot determine the type by any other means, the type of is assumed.
propertyList
name The name of the property.
[type] The type of the collection ().
[defaultValueType] The element base type.
Property lists are properties that implement the interface. The list element contains an optional constructor element and one or more object child elements that make up the elements in the collection. The object items must either be of the value type specified or be assignable to that type.
propertyDictionary
name The name of the property.
[type]
The type of the collection ().
[defaultKeyType] The type of keys in the collection.
[defaultValueType] The type of the values in the collection.
Similar to the property list, property dictionary collections must inherit from and contain optional constructor element and one or more item child elements that make up the element in the collection. Keys and values in the child elements must be of or assignable to the corresponding types defined for the collection.
item
[key] The key for this map item.
[value] The value for this map item.
Represents an item in property dictionary. It may contain child key and value elements.
key See object
Child of an item element that represents the key of the item. It is semantically equivalent to the object element.
value See object
Child of an item element that represents the value of the item. It is semantically equivalent to the object element.
The type for object, property, propertyList, or propertyDictionary item value is determined by the following rules:
Declared types take precedence.
If element is property then use parent object's corresponding named property type.
If element is inside propertyList, then use the defaultValueType.
If element is inside propertyDictionary, then use defaultValueType or defaultKeyType.
If the type is still , use .
A comprehensive test configuration file is shipped with in its bin folder under its installation location. This file demonstrates almost all scenarios usages with object builder 2 against its schema.
Specifying types in ObjectBuilder XML Almost all the elements in the XML schema have one or more type attributes that specify the type of the object or the type of its contained members or elements. In all cases, the framework adheres to the .NET standard for specifying types by strings. In general, type names must be fully qualified, for example:
TopNamespace.SubNameSpace.ClassName,MyAssembly
Types that are defined within shared assemblies loaded from the GAC must specify the assembly strong name in the type string to ensure the proper assembly and type are loaded:
System.Collections.Specialized.StringCollection, System, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089"
A partially qualified name is sufficient if the type is defined within mscorlib.dll or Hca.DevBlocks.Common.dll. However, it is always acceptable to specify the fully qualified name of a type.
.NET also allows for application-wide definition of short-name to strong-name aliases, using the <qualifyAssembly> configuration element.
Specifying Types in ObjectBuilder
type="Hca.Common.Service.ServiceConfig" Okay - is defined in Hca_DevBlocks_Common.dll.
type="System.String" Okay - is defined in mscorlib.dll.
type="System.Collections.Specialized.StringCollection" Insufficient - is defined in system.dll and must be fully qualified. (See details above.)
For more information on fully qualified type names in .NET please refer to .

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Builder.ToStringFormatter.ToString(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Implements the method to provide formatting using a .

remarks.para: creates a new instance of a that reflects the formatting and detail tags specified. The object that is passed into the constructor of this object will be converted to its string representation by the and returned.
Styles: SM TABBED_MULTI_LINE_STYLE, sm MULTI_LINE_STYLE, sn NO_FIELD_NAMES_STYLE, ss SIMPLE_STYLE
Levels: ds SummaryDetail, df FullDetail, dr FullRecursiveDetail
To specify detail and formatting the style must be specified followed by the detail level. Either may be omitted.
remarks.code: string str = String.Format("{0:[sm, dr]}", new ToStringFormatter(someObject));
remarks.para: See and for the meaning of styles and detail levels.

member.returns: A String containing the value of the current instance in the specified format.

summary.para: Controls string formatting for . The main public interface is always via .

remarks.para: These classes are intended to be used as Singletons. There is no need to instantiate a new style each time. A program will generally use one of the predefined constants on this class.

If required, a subclass can override as many or as few of the methods as it requires. All value types and reference types are handled to . Most have three levels of detail, , , and . , for the most part, will give terse output. For example it will not output the contents of an array but only give its size. goes a step farther and will output the members of an array and call the ToString on any other objects. will traverse the entire object graph using recursion. It is possible to set a class to stop traversing and/or the level at which to stop traversing the graph.

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Builder.ToStringStyle.Append(System.Text.StringBuilder,System.String,System.Object,System.Type)
member.overloads: Appends an object's string representation to the string buffer using the style of this object.
member.summary:
Appends an object's string representation to the string buffer using the style of this object.
The and parameters both allow values. If the target type is and the object is not then the type will be inferred from the target. If both are then the null text will be appended. If the is and not the type then will be returned allowing for a style to specify the type that is . If and both have a value but the type does not match the target then type will be changed to the type of the target object.
member.param: Name of the field if there is one
The target object to append to the string
The type of the object. You can obtain this from the object.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Collection.HashSet
member.summary: Implements a based on a .

remarks.para: Performance of the is efficient for most sized collections though its shows best performance in comparison to other possible backing data structures for large sets. Iteration produces elements in no particular order. Use the if you need items ordered. Element order is also indeterminate for any of the various mathematical operators.

A supports both heterogeneous and homogeneous collections. Since, sets are value based where the same value must not be allowed to be added, special hash and comparison is done to ensure that ANY object type added will only be added if its value is not the same. Hence, if you have object types that use special comparison or hashing and want to use that, you must specify this on construction. Note however, that if you take control, you are responsible for writing comprehensive hash code and comparison algorithms otherwise, you may have indeterminate results.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Collection.Set
member.summary: A collection that contains no duplicate elements. This class models the mathematical set abstraction, and is the base class for the other implementations in this library.

remarks.para: The order of elements in a set is dependant on (a) the data-structure implementation, and (b) the implementation of the various set methods, and thus is not specified here.
None of the implementations in this library are guaranteed to be thread-safe in any way unless wrapped in a .
All but the (due to semantics) are heterogeneous sets. Comparisons with heterogeneous sets can be compared as with any set.
remarks.note: When a is created via Clone(), a shallow copy occurs and hence the elements themselves are NOT cloned. If this is not your expectation or need, use to also copy the elements.
remarks.para: The following table summarizes the binary operations that are supported by the class.

item.term: Element included in result if it exists in either A OR B.
Element included in result if it exists in both A AND B.
Element included in result if it exists in one, but not both, of A and B.
Take all the elements in A. Now, if any of them exist in B, remove them. Note that unlike the other operators, A - B is not the same as B - A.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.ISet
member.summary: A collection that contains no duplicate elements. This interface models the mathematical set abstraction.

remarks.para: The order of elements in a set is dependant on (a) the data-structure implementation, and (b) the implementation of the various set methods, and thus is not specified here.
All of the implementations in this library are derived from the abstract base class. No instances are guaranteed to be thread-safe in any way unless wrapped in a .
The following table summarizes the binary set operations that are supported by the interface.

item.term: Element included in result if it exists in either A OR B.
Element included in result if it exists in both A AND B.
Element included in result if it exists in one, but not both, of A and B.
Take all the elements in A. Now, if any of them exist in B, remove them. Note that unlike the other operators, A - B is not the same as B - A.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Collection.HashSet.SetCompareWrapper
member.summary: This class provides a specialized comparator for handling the semantics we desire for placing items in a set.

remarks.p: Essentially, all we really want is for the equality check to use our value based comparator. However, since our only hook is via the comparer, we must implement the greater and less than checks. For our purposes, we really don't care about order since this is a set. Additionally since we want to support heterogenous collections for a set, we don't want to get an exception due to wrong types. Hence, we just always return one to optimize usage.
remarks.note: This comparer does not abide by the contract of .

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Collection.HashSet.SetCompareWrapper.Compare(System.Object,System.Object)
member.returns: -1 if < , 0 if == , and 1 if >

remarks.p: This wrapper provides a means to ensure that a given set can not be changed when accessed through this wrapper. As such, this class can only ensure that the underlying set will remain constant given no client gets access to that basisSet.

Operations (Union, Intersection, Minus, Xor) will return 's that are of the type of the wrapped set and are mutable. Hence, if you desire the resultant set of these operations to be immutable, you must wrap it in a new

summary.p: The System.Collections namespace in the .NET Framework provides a number of collection types that are extremely useful for manipulating data in memory. However, there is one type of collection that is conspicuously missing from : the Set.
A Set is a collection that contains no duplicate elements, and where the order of the elements may be arbitrary. It is modeled after the mathematical concept of a "set."

With sets, adding elements, removing elements, and checking for the existence of an element is fast and simple. You can mix and match the elements in different sets using the supported mathematical set operators: union, intersection, exclusive-or, and minus.

Sets come in handy when an Array or a List won't quite fit the bill. Arrays in .NET have a fixed length, making it tedious to add and remove elements. Lists allow you add new objects easily, but you can have numerous duplicate elements, which is undesirable for some types of problems. Searching Arrays or Lists for elements is just plain slow for large data sets, requiring a linear search. You could keep the array sorted and use a binary search, but that is often more trouble than it is worth (especially since this library, and the .NET Framework, provide better ways that are already written for you).

remarks.p: This namespace provides two general implementations of a set: and . A uses a backing hashtable to manage items. Items are not ordered in a . A can hold both homogeneous and heterogeneous items. In contrast, a is ordered but requires that all items to be of the same type (homogeneous) and implement . A is slower than the primarily due to the need to sort the items for additions, and update indexing when an item is removed. However, SortedSet.Contains checks are as fast as HashSet.Contains.

In addition to the two set types, two special purpose sets are provided: and . The is a wrapper that prevents modification of a set through its interface. This may be useful if you desire to return a set where you can ensure that the client can not modify that set. The provides thread-safe operation of a set.

An element in a set is deemed the same if a current element in the set "equals" the passed element. In terms of set theory, "equality" pertains to value-based equality. For example, 1 and 1 are equal regardless of whether held in a primitive or stored in different object instances. Since .Net only does value based semantics by default for value-types, care must be taken when using an object reference. Developers must consider two different scenarios of use when dealing with classes that use reference semantic equality: 1) Storage of the same value but considered different due to different object references and 2) Changes to a stored object where the value changes.

In the first case, per set semantics, we would expect a Set to find a current object whose value equals the value of the object to add. Since this would not happen normally, developers must either provide an alternative object when using hash-based implementations of a Set or ensure that the hash code and equality return the same value regardless of reference. As mentioned previously, the easiest path is to ensure your class inherits from or at least uses the and provided to implement and .

In the second case, it is advised that you do not use the object as the key to any set operation. Further, if the goal is to store a persistent (i.e., an object with and ObjectId) object in a Set, use the ObjectId as a key such that you can replace the existing value with the new if changed and using a hash-based implementation.
If you derive the object stored in a Set from , you many work with sets without concern of equality when adding values. However, as just discussed changes to those objects still must be considered.

Comparison is only a concern when using the . However, when used, developers must implement their Object's implementation such that all values are considered in the type for equality when used with the default Comparer built into the . The reason for this is that equality within a set is based on the entire value of the item. If a comparer chooses to use only one part of the value, then the equality check in the will not be the same as the comparison for equality done by the set. Hence, if you need to define that only considers a subset of value in an object, also define a comparer for the that is set on construction that also uses those subset of values to determine equality.
remarks.note: The constructors on that take a and should not normally be used except in very special cases. When used, care must be taken that no duplicate values are allowed since this would break the general contract and indeterminate results will occur from all operations (i.e., if you take control, correctness is up to you.
remarks.p: Iteration over a Set will always return the values and not some intermediate form from the underlying implementation such as DictionaryEntry. This allows sets to be worked on generically from the interface. It also has a side benefit that the enumeration will remain constant for the duration of iteration even when the base collection the enumeration was created from changes.

You will see some interesting side effects with different Set implementations in this library, depending on the underlying search algorithm. For example, if you choose a sort-based Set, the elements will come out in sort order when you iterate using foreach. If you use a hash-based Set, the elements will come out in no particular order, but checking for inclusion will be fastest when dealing with large data sets.

example.p: Although there are other kinds of sets available in the library, the example uses throughout. This is nice for the example, since everything will print neatly in alphabetical order. But you may be wondering what kind of Set is returned when you "union," "intersect," "exclusive-or," or "minus" two Set instances. The library always returns a Set that is the same type as the Set on the left, unless the left operand is null, in which case it returns the type of the Set on the right.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Collection.SortedSet
member.summary: Implements a based on a .

remarks.para: The sorted implementation gives good performance for operations on very large data-sets, though not as good - asymptotically - as a . However, iteration occurs in order. Elements that you put into this type of collection must implement , and they must actually be comparable. You can't mix and values, for example.

When defining classes that may be put in a , be sure that the comparer is based on the entire value of the object. If it does not, then no guarantees can be made about operations on this set. As an alternative to prevent this, you can create a that can be passed on construction of a . This will allow the internal implementation to use just this comparer for all actions.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Collection.SynchronizedSet
member.summary: Implements a thread-safe wrapper.

remarks.p: This implementation is extremely conservative, serializing critical sections to prevent possible deadlocks, and locking on everything.

This class does not synchronize any collection passed as an argument. Hence if this is an expected need, you must synchronize that set before passing into a synchronized operation. The reason for this is that in normal use, synchronization may not be needed on that set and hence, the overhead of doing this can be eliminated.

member.name: P:Hca.Common.Configuration.AssemblyConfigurationFileAttribute.FileName
member.summary: Gets the name of the configuration file to load when the marked assembly is in use.

remarks.para: If is , this is the name of a resource file linked into the marked assembly. Otherwise, this is a file system path.

Relative paths are from the code base location of the assembly to which this attribute is applied. This presents a problem for shared library assemblies which have been loaded into the GAC, because their actual code base location is controlled by Windows. handles this situation using the functionality provided by ; thus, developers should set a code base registry key for any shared library deployed to the GAC.
remarks.note: The value of this property is set by the class constructor.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Configuration.ConfigFactory
member.summary: Loads configuration object definitions from the configuration store and builds and caches the objects as they are requested.

remarks.para: This class is implemented as a singleton - that is, there is never more than one instance of in a given application domain. The static property constructs and then accesses that instance.
The and methods are used to retrieve objects defined in the configuration store. , , and allow clients to dynamically manipulate what is included in the configuration store.

watches the configuration store after loading and rebuilds its cache when it detects changes. The event is raised when this rebuild is complete. A rebuild may be forced by a client through a call to .
remarks.note: A five-second "queueing period" intervenes between when changes are detected and when the rebuild is initiated. This keeps from thrashing unnecessarily in the case of additional near-simultaneous changes. The rebuild begins when no additional changes have been detected for a period of five seconds.
remarks.para: Please see the namespace overview for a complete walk-through of the functionality provided by .

member.overloads: Searches the configuration store for a single instance of a given concrete .
member.summary: Searches the configuration store for a single instance of a given concrete in the default (unspecified) context, throwing an exception if no match is found.
member.returns: An instance of as defined in the configuration store. The return value may be cast directly to the type specified by .
member.exception: Thrown if is or does not derive from .

exception.para: Thrown if no objects match the request
if multiple objects match the request
if some other error occurs while accessing the configuration store.

member.exception: Thrown if is defined in a different assembly than the calling code (unless is marked [InsecureConfig]).

remarks.para: This method calls the object's before returning.

Objects defined in the configuration store are instantiated on a just-in-time basis. The first time a particular object is requested, creates and validates it, and then caches a reference to it. Duplicate requests then return that same reference.

remarks.para: This method retrieves an object of from the specified in the configuration store. Before it is returned, the object is asked to validate its state (calling ).
If no definition matching this request can be found, this method's behavior is determined by the value of : if , is returned; if , a is thrown.
If more than one definition matching this request is found, a is thrown.

Configuration object definitions are instantiated on a just-in-time basis. The first time a particular request is made, creates and initializes the instance per the definition, and then caches it before returning. Future requests then return the instance that was cached at the first request.

The first time a particular request is made, creates and initializes the instances per their definitions, and then caches them before returning. Future requests then return the instances that were cached at the first request.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Configuration.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
The namespace contains classes implementing a rich framework for configuring applications declaratively with XML.
Contents
This document introduces the concepts that comprise the configuration framework. It contains the following sections:
Configuration Files
Describes the XML files that make up the configuration store - how they are formatted, where they can reside, how they are located by the framework, and how changes are handled after loading.
XML Syntax, Types of Files, Locating Files, Watching Changes, Encrypting Sensitive Values, Read-Only Configurations
Object Definitions
Describes how individual configuration objects are defined in configuration files - how they are formatted, how they reference their defining class, and how they are organized.
XML Syntax, Organizing Configuration Objects into Contexts
Token Definitions
Describes how string tokens are defined and referenced in configuration files.
XML Syntax
Examples
Illustrates a complete walk-through of creating a configuration class, defining an instance in XML, and retrieving that instance from .
Subclass, XML Configuration Files, Calling GetConfig, Custom Validation
Development Guidelines
Describes the basic guidelines for designing and implementing configuration classes and files.
Tenets Best Practices
Application Programming Interface
Summarizes the public types used by clients to interact with the configuration framework.
Classes
Additional information relevant to usage of the configuration framework but not covered here may be found in the following locations:
Microsoft .NET 1.1 Configuration File Schema
Configuration Files
The declarative configuration store that is consumed and exposed by consists of one or more XML files. This section describes those files - how they are formatted, where they can reside, how they are located by the framework, and how changes are handled after loading.
XML Syntax
All configuration files contain a single hcaConfigFactory XML element. The following example illustrates this element along with the elements it may contain:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <cf:hcaConfigFactory xmlns:cf="http://hcaschema.hca.corpad.net/Common/Configuration/2.0/ConfigFactory.xsd" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://hcaschema.hca.corpad.net/Common/Configuration/2.0/ConfigFactory.xsd" > <include ... /> <tokenDefault ... /> <token ... /> <config ... /> </cf:hcaConfigFactory>
Types of Files
The hcaConfigFactory element may be contained in three types of files. By convention, all configuration file names should have the .config extention. (This practice has the added benefit of making configuration files inaccessible to web clients in ASP.NET.)
Basic File in the File System
The most basic form of configuration file has the hcaConfigFactory element as the root of an XML text file on disk. The ?xml processing directive is optional.
File Resource Embedded in a .NET Assembly
The configuration framework can also access an XML file with the hcaConfigFactory root element that has been linked into a .NET assembly as file resource.
Section Inside the .NET Configuration File
Finally, the configuration framework also recognizes the hcaConfigFactory element inside .NET's configuration file ([App].config/web.config) as long as it is declared in the configSections element. This is illustrated below: The cf: prefix is mandatory.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <configSections> <section name="cf:hcaConfigFactory" type="Hca.Common.Configuration.SectionHandler, Hca_DevBlocks_Common, Version=1.3.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=FD260FD4A2A56402" /> </configSections> <cf:hcaConfigFactory ... /> </configuration>
Locating Files The configuration framework identifies files that should be included in its store in three ways.
The "Primary" Configuration File
By default, looks for an hcaConfigFactory element inside .NET's configuration file. This is considered the 'primary' configuration file. However, consuming applications may override this behavior and point to an alternative file on disk. This is illustrated in the following example:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="Hca.Common.ConfigFactory.ConfigFile" value="MyPrimary.config" /> </appSettings> </configuration>
Assembly "Bootstrap" Configuration Files
Individual assemblies can inform of configuration needed for 'bootstraping' by applying the assembly-level [AssemblyConfigurationFile] attribute. These files are loaded into the configuration store independent of the 'primary' configuration. This is illustrated in the following code: Please see for details on constructor arguments.
using Hca.Common.Configuration;
// A file embedded inside this assembly. [assembly:AssemblyConfigurationFile("Hca.Common.EmbedFile.Common.config")]
// A file path relative to this assembly's code base. [assembly:AssemblyConfigurationFile("ExternalFile.config", )]
"Include" References
Finally, any configuration file may direct to 'include' other configuration files located either on disk or embedded in an assembly. Typically, includes will refer to physical files deployed with the application or assembly and not embedded within an assembly since the "bootstrap" mechanism describe above is the preferred means for an assembly to load its embedded defintion. However, there may be cases where this is needed or preferred and hence the example that follow shows how this would be done. The XML syntax for these references is illustrated below: Relative paths in 'include' references are relative to the file containing the reference, unless that file is embedded in an assembly - in that case, they are relative to the application domain's .
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <cf:hcaConfigFactory ... > <!-- A file path relative to the application. --> <include filename="Environmental.config" />
<!-- A file resource linked into an assembly. --> <include filename="Hca.Application.EmbedFile.Embeddedconfig" assembly="Hca.Application, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=0123456789ABCDEF" />
<!-- A conditional reference. --> <include filename="..\Conditional.config" includeid="conditional" /> <tokenDefault ... /> <token ... /> <config ... /> </cf:hcaConfigFactory>
As illustrated, includes may be designated as conditional by declaring an includeid attribute. Any reference with an includeid will by default be ignored by . Use to enable a conditional include.
Watching Changes
A key advantage of this configuration framework is that configuration changes may be applied to the application while it is still running. Whenever a configuration file loaded from the file system is modified (or deleted) will clear its cache and reload the store, starting with the 'bootstrap' and 'primary' configuration files and again tracing through all 'include' references they contain. When this completes, clients are notified by the event, and changes are immediately reflected in subsequent calls to and .
However, it is important to note that only files loaded directly from the file system are watched for changes:
File resources linked into an assembly are not watched. Embedded resources cannot change unless the assembly changes, and assembly changes cannot be applied without unloading the application domain.
The .NET configuration file is not watched. .NET loads this file only once during the lifetime of the application domain. This is a moot issue in ASP.NET, because the whole application is recycled automatically whenever web.config is modified.
Encrypting Sensitive Values
The configuration framework detects and decrypts basic configuration files that have been encrypted. The encryption tool used at deployment time finds all .config files with cf:hcaConfigFactory as the root element, and encrypts each one, changing the file name extension to .encrypted.config. In turn, always checks first for a file with the .encrypted.config whenever it is directed to a .config.
Hence, the only action required of developers to protect sensitive configuration is to make sure all sensitive values are contained in basic file system configuration files. (Encryption is not supported for files linked into assemblies or for the section inside .NET's configuration file.)
Read-Only Configurations
The Configuration Framework allows for a configuration element to be marked as read-only. This indicates to the framework that items in the section are not meant to be changed.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <cf:hcaConfigFactory...> <config type="Hca.Library.LibraryConfig, Hca.Library, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=0123456789ABCDEF" context="shortTimeout" readonly="true" > <property name="Timeout" value="500" /> </config> <config ... /> </cf:hcaConfigFactory>
However, simply marking the config section as read-only does not guarantee the items in the section are protected from being changed. In the configuration class that maps to the configuration file, the setter property needs to check to see if the item is marked as read-only before writing to it. The following example shows how this is done.
using System; using System.Reflection;
namespace Hca.Library { [Serializable] public class LibraryConfig : ConfigBase { [Required] private int timeout;
public int TimeOut { get { return timeout; } set { CheckWritable(MethodInfo.GetCurrentMethod()); timeout = value; } } } }
Object Definitions
Configuration objects are instances of classes derived from , built by based on declarative object defintions in configuration files. This section describes how these definitions are formatted and how they are organized.
XML Syntax
Each object is defined by a config XML element inside hcaConfigFactory in a configuration file. These definitions are loaded by and parsed by . The following example illustrates defining configuration objects in a configuration file: The configuration schema's config element is derived from 's object element. Please see for details on the XML schema it expects.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <cf:hcaConfigFactory ... > <include ... /> <tokenDefault ... /> <token ... /> <config type="Hca.Library.LibraryConfig, Hca.Library, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=0123456789ABCDEF" context="longTimeout" > <property name="Timeout" value="15000" /> <property name="TimeoutMessage">The patient clock says, "you're out of time!"</property> </config> <config type="Hca.Library.LibraryConfig, Hca.Library, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=0123456789ABCDEF" context="shortTimeout" readonly="true" > <property name="Timeout" value="500" /> <property name="TimeoutMessage">The impatient clock says, "you're out of time!"</property> </config> <config ... /> </cf:hcaConfigFactory>
Organizing Configuration Objects into Contexts
Some subclasses are intended for the equivalent of singleton usage - only one instance is ever used in any given application domain. allows such objects to be retrieved simply by specifying the in a call to . However, some subclasses may have many instances within a single application. Often, all of those instances are still consumed by a single object, which will retrieve them using .
Many configuration classes, though, will have multiple instances consumed by different objects. In that case, each consuming object must have a way of directing to the particular instance or instances that were intended for it (as disctinct from those intended for consumption by other objects). For situations such as this, the configuration framework provides a concept called 'context'.
A context is a handle used by a client to request a subset of instances of a particular subclass. Every object defintion in the configuration store is associated with one or more contexts. The context(s) with which a config element is to be associated is specified by its context attribute, which can contain one or more context names. Multiple context names are delimited by commas (which will be stripped of leading and trailiing spaces). If the context attribute is omitted, then the 'default' context is assumed. The default context may be explicitly specified by an empty string attribute value, or in the case of a list, by an extra comma. (I.e., context="a, , b" associates a configuration object with context a, context b, and the default context.
For client consumption of contextual configuration, and both accept a context parameter which limits the scope of the search to those instances of the specified class that are associated with the specified context name. If this parameter is not specified, then the search is limited to the default context.
Token Definitions
Typically, any value that should be part of a configuration object is specified literally in the configuration object definition. However, in some cases (such as a complex configuration with only one or two values that are likely to change, or multiple configuration objects repeating the same value), extracting a value to another seperate location in the configuration store is helpful. The configuration framework supports tokenization of values, allowing a named, string-valued token to be defined once, and then referenced from any number of object defintions (without any special handling by the affected objects' classes). This section describes how string tokens are defined and referenced in configuration files.
XML Syntax
A token is defined using a token element. This element specifies the token name and value as attributes. Configuration object definitions can then reference that token in any value string by surrounding the token name with a pair of @ characters. A token may also be referenced by the value attribute of another token definition using the same syntax.
Tokens may be defined in one file and consumed in another, as long as both files are included in the configuration store. Apparent token references which do not match a defined token name will be passed through by the framework as literal strings containing two @ characters. Common practice is to tokenize all environment-specific values throughout the configuration store, and then define them all in a single included configuration file named Environmental.config.
It is an error to specify two token elements with the same name anywhere in the configuration store. However, the framework does supports the concept of a default value for a token which may be overridden. The default value is specified by a tokenDefault element, which contains a name and value. That value will be used unless a token element also specifies the same name, in which case the value of the token element will take precedence. Token defaults are primarily intended for scenarios where default configuration is embedded in a library, but may be overridden in the configuration store of a consuming application.
The following example illustrates the syntax for defining and referencing tokens: The configuration object's Letter property will be configured with the string "The letter is: b!".
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <cf:hcaConfigFactory ... > <include ... /> <tokenDefault name="myToken1" value="a" /> <token name="myToken1" value="b" /> <token name="myToken2" value="@myToken1@" /> <config ... > <property name="Letter" value="The letter is: @myToken2@!" /> </config> </cf:hcaConfigFactory>
Examples
This section illustrates a complete walk-through of creating a configuration class, defining an instance in XML, and retrieving that instance from . The class is a subclass used by Common to allow applications to override the behavior of certain low-level functions.
Subclass
The class is defined in CommonConfig.cs and compiled into Hca_DevBlocks_Common.
using System; using System.Reflection;
namespace Hca.Common.Configuration { [Serializable] public class CommonConfig : ConfigBase { [Required] private string excludeNameSpacesPrefixedWith; private bool useOptimisticLocking;
public string ExcludeNamespacesPrefixedWith { get { return excludeNameSpacesPrefixedWith; } set { CheckWritable(MethodInfo.GetCurrentMethod()); excludeNameSpacesPrefixedWith = SystemUtility.NullOrTrimString(value); } }
public bool UseOptimisticLocking { get { return useOptimisticLocking; } set { CheckWritable(MethodInfo.GetCurrentMethod()); useOptimisticLocking = value; } } } }
XML Configuration Files
The XML object definition is contained in CommonConfig.cs, linked into Hca_DevBlocks_Common with an assembly-level attribute in AssemblyInfo.cs.
Some application's Web.config file contains the 'primary' configuration, and 'include's Environmental.config, which contains token values for configuration specific to each deployment environment.
using Hca.Common.Configuration;
// ... [assembly:AssemblyConfigurationFile("Hca.Common.EmbedFile.Common.config")]
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <cf:hcaConfigFactory xmlns:cf="http://hcaschema.hca.corpad.net/Common/Configuration/2.0/ConfigFactory.xsd" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://hcaschema.hca.corpad.net/Common/Configuration/2.0/ConfigFactory.xsd" >
<tokenDefault name="Hca.Common.Configuration.CommonConfig.ExcludeNamespacesPrefixedWith" value="System" /> <tokenDefault name="Hca.Common.Configuration.CommonConfig.UseOptimisticLocking" value="true" />
<config type="Hca.Common.Configuration.CommonConfig, Hca_DevBlocks_Common, Version=1.3.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=FD260FD4A2A56402" readOnly="true"> <property name="ExcludeNamespacesPrefixedWith" value="@Hca.Common.Configuration.CommonConfig.ExcludeNamespacesPrefixedWith@"/> <property name="UseOptimisticLocking" value="@Hca.Common.Configuration.CommonConfig.UseOptimisticLocking@"/> </config>
<!-- ... --> </cf:hcaConfigFactory>
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration>
<configSections> <section name="cf:hcaConfigFactory" type="Hca.Common.Configuration.SectionHandler, Hca_DevBlocks_Common, Version=1.3.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=FD260FD4A2A56402" /> </configSections>
<cf:hcaConfigFactory xmlns:cf="http://hcaschema.hca.corpad.net/Common/Configuration/2.0/ConfigFactory.xsd" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://hcaschema.hca.corpad.net/Common/Configuration/2.0/ConfigFactory.xsd" >
<include filename="Environmental.config" />
</cf:hcaConfigFactory>
<system.web ... />
</configuration>
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <cf:hcaConfigFactory xmlns:cf="http://hcaschema.hca.corpad.net/Common/Configuration/2.0/ConfigFactory.xsd" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://hcaschema.hca.corpad.net/Common/Configuration/2.0/ConfigFactory.xsd" >
<!-- Override tokenDefault from Common's embedded configuration. --> <token name="Hca.Common.Configuration.CommonConfig.UseOptimisticLocking" value="false" />
</cf:hcaConfigFactory>
Calling
The configuration object is consumed by ValueObjectBase.cs, also compiled into Hca_DevBlocks_Common.
using System; using Hca.Common.Configuration;
namespace Hca.Common.BaseType { public abstract class ValueObjectBase : ModelBase { private static bool isOptimisticLockingOn = false;
static ValueObjectBase() { CommonConfig config = (CommonConfig) ConfigFactory.Instance.GetConfig(typeof(CommonConfig)); isOptimisticLockingOn = config.UseOptimisticLocking; }
// ... } }
Overriding
If a configuration class contains items that need special validation, you can override and add the appropriate validation code there. Generally, this is not necessary for most configuration classes. If the validation fails, you should throw an exception. You can only throw or a sub-class of that exception.
using System; using Hca.Common.Configuration;
namespace Hca.Library { public class MyConfig : ConfigBase { private int customItem;
public int CustomItem { get { return customItem; } set { customItem = value; } }
protected override void ValidateCustom() { // perform custom validation here
// if the validation fails, throw an exception. if ( validationFailed ) { throw new HcaConfigurationException(); } }
// ... } }
Guidelines
The following sections identify the basic tenets and best practices for implementing configuration classes and files.
Tenets The following tenets should be adhered when utilizing the configuration framework.
All configuration classes must extend .
Avoid configuration classes that are merely collections of miscellaneous values. Configuration information should be organized into cohesive classes.
Keep the structure of each configuration class as simple as possible.
Application configuration information should be cleanly separated from target and platform configuration.
Configuration objects may throw only .
Best Practices The Configuration Framework provides a robust and consistent means for configuring applications and the components with which they interact. Ideally, once system administrators are familiar with the Configuration Framework, they can determine how the application is configured by just reviewing its configuration files, regardless of the systems underlying architecture or domain. To accomplish this, the following guidelines should be used.
Avoid configuration classes that are unrelated collections of values.
Configuration classes should represent a cohesive concept that is readily recognizable to those who are familiar with the system domain.
Keep the structure of configuration classes as simple as is possible. Complex classes require complex XML object definitions. Unnecessary complexity makes maintenance difficult and error-prone.
Use the advanced features of the configuration framework sparingly. The Configuration Framework provides many powerful tools for object instantiation. However, many of the advanced features add extra complexity to the process and are not usually required. If you have a habit of using many of the Frameworks more advanced features, you may want to review your design for opportunities to simplify it.
Application configuration information should be clearly separate target and platform configuration. Applications should consistently use the Configuration Framework rather than using platform specific methods of configuration like app.config. Configuration information specific to the underlying target, platform, or operating system should continue to use the platform specific methods. Doing this ensures that configuration remains robust and portable across targets and platforms.
Configuration classes should use the Config suffix as a convention (e.g., ServiceConfig, ExceptionConfig, etc.).
Consider nomenclature carefully when creating configuration classes. Remember that configuration objects are not defined and maintained in a vacuum; the names you choose for classes and properties will be seen by system administrators. Try to choose names that convey meaning easily understood by domain users and administrators.
Application Programming Interface
This section summarizes the types exposed by the configuration framework.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.DataType.Address
member.summary: This class provides a concrete Address implementation that uses codified values for common terminology properties of Location (address type), State, Country, and County.
member.remarks:
See remarks for additional information on when to use as opposed to .
Address Property Semantics
Property Usage
The place that is designated by the address. This is a codified value and represents locations such as home, business, etc.
The id of the state of the address. This is a codified value and represents the state.
The id of the country of the address. This is a codified value and represents the country.
The id of the county of the address. This is a codified value and represents the county.
All of the fields that adds to are codified. This means that only the code for the item is stored - not the text or description of the item. The connection between the codified values and the text lookup is managed through an . This renderer should be configured through . The following example illustrates this configuration.
member.example:
<config type="Hca.Common.Service.ServiceConfig" readOnly="true" context="ICodeRenderer"> 
            	<Property name="serviceType" value="Hca.Facility.CodeManagement.CodeProvider"/> 
            	<Property name="Creator" value="Hca.Common.Service.SingletonTypeCreator"/> 
            </config>
            
            
            

            	Example that illustrates how to set values using the constructor.
            	The numerical values are fake codified values.
            	

            	
            		
            Address a = new Address ("115 Center Street", "Apt. A", "Nashville", "37201", 400, 8938, 7234, 9981);
            		
            	
            	

            	Example that illustrates how to set values using the property accessors.
            	The numerical values are fake codified values.
            	

            	
            		
            Address a = new Address ();
            a.StreetAddress = "115 Center Street";
            a.AddressLine2 = "Apt. A";
            a.City = "Nashville";
            a.CountyId = 8938;
            		
            		
            	
            	

            	Example that illustrates how to format the object into a string.  This method generates a 
            	standard mailing address. Note that the  method is shared by both 
            	 and  
            	and hence the same example applies to  other 
            	than the code values would be replaced by text values.
            	

            	
            		
            Address address1 = new Address("100 Main St.", "Suite 100", "Nashville", "37214", 100, 201, 33);
            
            // assume 100, 201, and 33 are keys for codes
            address1.EffectiveDate = new Date(2004, 2, 6);
            
            string output = address1.ToString("M", CultureInfo.CurrentCulture);
            // returns: 100 Main St.\nSuite 100\nNashville . . . 
            
            // Print for another culture
            CultureInfo fr = new CultureInfo("fr-FR", false);
            String output = address1.ToString("V", fr);
            //returns: InCareOf: \nStreetAddress: 100 Main St.\nAddressLine2: Suite 100\nCity: Nashville\n
            State: 100\nPostalZone: 37214\nPostalZonePlusFour: \nCountry: 201\nCounty: 33\nEffectiveDate: 06/02/2004\n
            EndDate: \nIsDeliverable: \nIsPoBox: \nLocation: 1\n
            
            // Use a custom format
            String output = address1.ToString("{L1} {c} {s},{z}", CultureInfo.CurrentCulture);
            // returns: 100 Main St. Nashville 100,37214

member.name: T:Hca.Common.DataType.AddressBase
member.summary: This class provides support to represent both domestic and international addresses. This class supports flags for indication of standardization (USPS standards) which may be a requirement for storage. Additionally, validations on whether the address is deliverable (CASS certified) can be indicated through the property. holds the standard postal address for any country. If a US address is represented, should hold the 4 digit part of the zip code.
member.remarks:
is the abstract base class for the codified and the textual . Both derived classes provide the same level of semantics but are intended for use in different scenarios. is suited for applications that have control of the data entry of values that would make up the address. In particular, the codified values need to driven from the legal set of codes for that term (e.g. all valid states for ) to ensure consistency in representation. However, there are cases where data is from a foreign system and the application cannot control the data that is provided. In these cases, may be better suited since it accepts the text value as is and does not need a provider to translate between the coded form and the display form. For example, if a legacy system only stores the value of the State attribute and not a code, it would require translation between the text value and the codes that an application might use for this attribute. Further, if the foreign system did not restrict the values entered (e.g. allowed TN or Tenn or Tennessee for a State value) it may be impractical or impossible to provide reliable translation. Hence, allows for the value as entered to be used while maintaining the other features of . However, in general, it is highly recommended that codified terms be used whenever possible to allow for evolution and efficient communication of terms.
During design, consider using the base class as a member type if it is anticipated that the codified version of the address will be evidentially used.
and share these attributes:
Addressee (in care of)
Street Address and address Line 2
City
Zip Code (postal code) and Postal Zone + 4r
Whether it is a post office box
Dates when it starts and stops being valid.
also contains the following codified attributes:
State Id, County Id, and Country Id
Location Id (e.g. Home, Business, Vacation, etc.)
also contains the following attributes:
State Text, County Text, and Country Text
Location Text
The data elements of an address are set and retrieved through properties. Most of them can also be set through the overloaded constructor. However, the following properties must be set after the object is created: , , , . The semantics of the address fields that are not directly obvious are shown below.
Address Property Semantics
Property Usage
The physical numbered address.
For placement of information such as department, suite, or other designation that helps direct mail or identify the location of the address.
If the postal address in is the US, this the +4 portion of the zip code.
The date that address becomes available for use.
The date the address becomes invalid for use.
Used to indicate that the address has been validated either through CASS certification or another source (such as a utility bill).
The place that is designated by the address. This is a codified value and represents locations such as home, business, etc.
The displayable text for the location.
The id of the state of the address. This is a codified value and represents the state.
The displayable text for the state.
The id of the country of the address. This is a codified value and represents the country.
The displayable text for the country.
The id of the county of the address. This is a codified value and represents the county.
The displayable text for the county.
There are several items that are codified. This means that only the code for the item is stored - not the text or description of the item. The connection between the codified values and the text lookup is managed through an . This renderer should be configured through . The following example illustrates this configuration.
<config type="Hca.Common.Service.ServiceConfig" readOnly="true" context="ICodeRenderer"> <Property name="serviceType" value="Hca.Facility.CodeManagement.CodeProvider"/> <Property name="Creator" value="Hca.Common.Service.SingletonTypeCreator"/> </config>

member.name: T:Hca.Common.DataType.ICodeRenderer
member.summary: Signature for a code provider. Code providers manage retrieve the appropriate string representation for code keys.
member.remarks:
This interface allows for datatypes and other types that have codified values to get different string representations of these codes given their keys.
This interface allows multiple renderers to be represented and used by types. For instance, you could use Code Management Facility or create your own renderer that maps to your schema. The renders should be configured for the and delineated by a context. A context of should return a contextless renderer or the default renderer. If no context was provided and a renderer was not found, the key should be returned as the display text and numeric form.

member.name: M:Hca.Common.DataType.AddressBase.CalculateHashKey

summary.p: This method calculates a hash value for the value-part of an address.

member.remarks:
The following fields are used for calculation of the value:
The intent of use for this method is to provide a key for the "value" part of the address such that when modeling one to many relationships of an entity to an address, the value part is stored only once for the same address value. For example, given relationships of contact address and home address, if both values were: 100 main St. AnyTown AnyState instead of storing this twice, you could use this key to store the address value (the properties listed previously) in one table and the relationship in another where the foreign key in the parent is this key.
If you change the the values that contribute to this key, you must call this method again to get the new key instead of updating the values at the old key. If a new value is created, it may need to be inserted since it may not exist. Cleanup of values should be based on whether history needs to be maintained for historical address values. If not, some form of reference counting needs to be used so it is known when a value can be cleaned up. This is up to the client application to provide.
member.returns: A hash ( )for the current address value

member.name: M:Hca.Common.DataType.AddressBase.ToString
member.overloads: Returns a string representation of the current address.
member.summary: Returns the general format string of implementation.

member.name: M:Hca.Common.DataType.AddressBase.ToString(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: This method provides specialized formatting of an address based on the passed character(s) in the format argument.
member.remarks:
The format can be specified in two different ways.
Standard Formats
The first way is by specifying one of the Standard Formats:
G or g (General format) Default if not specified.
M (Mailing Address) Returns a mailable Address.
V (Verbose) Returns a listing of the values of all fields.
Custom Formats
The second way is by specifying the address segments using these identifiers.
These formats are case insensitive:
{L1} Street Address; Line 1
{L2} Address Line 2
{C} City
{S} State
{Z} Postal Zone
{F} Postal Zone + 4
{R} Country
{N} County
Any unrecognized characters are repeated back into the output string as specified in the format string for the custom format.
If the format provided is not a standard format and none of the custom characters are recognized, the returned string is the format string as provided.
The { is treated as a delimiter of sorts and if you desire it to be in the output as a literal, you must escape it with a second left or right brace{ or } character. For example:
"{{C}"
will yield a parsed pattern of only the {C literal since the double left brace characters are consumed together. Instead, to have this appear as a brace followed by the {c} token, add a second left brace to the string. For example:
"{{{C}"
will yield a parsed pattern of a literal { followed by the C token {<C Token Value>.
Finally, to make this happen internally, we use unicode 0 and 1 as temporary replacement tokens. Hence these cannot be used as literal values in the format string. Given that these are not printable characters and this method is to generate a printable string, this is not a problem.
member.returns: The formatted address, or the format string if there are no parts of the format string that are recognizable.
member.exception: Thrown if Unicode character 0 or 1 is included in the format string.

member.summary: Returns the "G" format string of implementation.

member.name: M:Hca.Common.DataType.AuditDetail.ToString(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Provide a formatted string value
member.remarks:
This class provides for the standard format and a custom format. The formats are such:
Standard Format G, g, or no specification yields the standard value given the object. Custom Format The custom format tags are case insensitive.
{C} The Create time
{CI} The Identity of the create user
{U} The Update time
{UI} The Identity of the update user
Any unrecognized characters are repeated back into the output string as specified in the format string for the custom format.
If the format provided is not a standard format and none of the custom characters are recognized, the returned string is the format string as provided.
The { is treated as a delimiter of sorts and hence if you desire it to be in the output as a literal, you must escape it with a second left or right brace{ or } character. For example:
"{{C}"
will yield a parsed pattern of only the {C literal since the double left brace are consumed together. Instead, to have this appear as a brace followed by the {c} token, add a second left brace to the string. For example:
"{{{C}"
will yield a parsed pattern of a literal { followed by the C token {<C Token Value%gt;.
Finally, to make this happen internally, we use unicode 0 and 1 as temporary replacement tokens. Hence these cannot be used as literal values in the format string. Given that these are not printable characters and this method is to generate a printable string, this is not a problem.
member.exception: Thrown if Unicode character 0 or 1 is included in the format string.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.DataType.Date
member.summary: This class contains the date elements of the class (Month, Day, and Year). There is no time component.
member.remarks:
Functional Requirements This class provides a date-only representation.
Tenets The user should attempt to use values for only legitimate dates. Invalid values generate an error. For example, January 43, 2004 is not a valid date.
Design is a custom data type that stores the elements of a date (year, month, and day). This class does not have time elements. It is intended to be used when the developer is only concerned with the date segments of .
uses internally to validate, manipulate, and output the values. It strips out any time-specific values.
Usage should be used in any Value Object that requires a date-only property. It should be used instead of because does not store any time zone information.
Variables typed for this class can also be set to , indicating a not-set state. This is useful as data types for properties of any class that requires a partial update.
Exceptions are also thrown when instances are initialized with invalid dates .
Use or instead of .NET's .
Best Practices Use and as data a type for properties of Value Objects instead of . Additionally, when only a date is needed (such as representing a date of birth), use since it ensures that time components are not valued.
is associated with this type allowing two-way conversion.

hcaExample.desc: Example 10: Setting the values through the constructors
Example 11: Setting the values through SetDate

member.name: T:Hca.Common.DataType.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
Overview The namespace contains HCA specific data types similar to .NET's , , , etc. HCA's data types are rich objects designed to be contained by still richer value or transfer objects. For example, a patient usually has many addresses and phone numbers. Some of these data types augment .NET's data type implementations like augments . Other types have no equivalent objects in .NET, such as . These new data types make the code more robust. Some scenarios might not be needed in all circumstances. For example, you might not need to store postal zip code with the plus-4 part. In this case, it can be left out. However, if your requirements change, this property is available. The goal is to have new data types that are rich enough to handle most scenarios.
All data types contained in the namespace inherit from a base class named . The main purpose of this class is to provide an inheritance placeholder for future behavior abstraction as well as support for current codified behavior.
and are examples of codified data types.
Codified data types contain fields that are keys. These keys are usually a value in a lookup table. The key is persistent, referenced by other objects, and not the displayed lookup value. This provides flexibility because the actual display text for this key is decoupled from the key and can change if needed.
manages the relationship with code renderers, which helps classes with codified fields. Code renderers implement .
The code renderer used by the data type is determined by a configuration. The framework allows the data types to abstract themselves from the code renderer.
Each codified data type passes in a context that is unique for its codified property. For example, has a property named that represents the phone number's device (land line, fax, cell, etc.). The unique context for this field is "Hca.Common.DataType.PhoneNumber.DeviceType".
also has a property named . This property provides the display text value for the key or codified value deviceTypeId. It takes into consideration the current culture, the key's context, and the key itself as it passes this information to the base class to determine the text displayed.
The base class uses to retrieve a code renderer for a given context. If a code renderer is not found, then the base class will try and find one with no context. If a code renderer is not found, then a default code renderer will be used. The default code renderer returns the key as the display text. For new applications, the code renderer should be Code Management Facility's code provider and it should be defined with no context, indicating that it should be used for all contexts that are not explicitly defined. This pattern allows you to define multiple code renderers in situations where Code Management Facility is not appropriate and there is legacy code or it interacts with other systems.
Figure 1: DataTypeBase
Address, TextAddress, PersonName, PhoneNumber, TextPhoneNumber
Overview These classes are custom data types that represent a mailing address, a person's name, and a phone number. Applications use these classes when the concept is needed within a class or by that application. This ensures that the same data elements are used across different applications and facilitates consistent persistence of these concepts.
Requirements These classes need to represent all essential elements of each data type. Properties in these classes that are implemented by a primitive value type must support the not set state so that they can be used appropriately where partial updates are performed on the class. These classes are not intended to be used directly as value objects and do not inherit from . However, like any other standard data type, they can be used as parts of value objects.
For more information about value objects, see .
Tenets and have properties that are codified. This means that their values are codes that cross-reference to literal values. This codification is a means to abstract the concept from the actual usage in code. Consequently, the information it conveys can change over time without affecting the existing use of the codified value.
Usage These classes maintain address, name, and phone number information. They should be treated as standard data objects.
Configuration Codified values must have some code-to-text lookup functionality and/or configuration. classes rely on an to supply the code-to-text functionality. This renderer should be configured through ServiceFactory.
The configuration example shows a configuration for Code Provider which is the recommended code renderer. This configuration does not have a context defined so this renderer would be the default for all contexts. You can define specific renders for different contexts like location, state, country, county, etc. type asks for a code renderer for the following contexts:
Location
State
Country
County
type asks for a code renderer for the following contexts:
DeviceType
Location
If a renderer is not returned then it will look for a renderer with no context and finally use its own renderer if none is found.
<config type="Hca.Common.Service.ServiceConfig" readOnly="true"> <property name="Interface" value="Hca.Common.DataType.ICodeRenderer"/> <property name="Creator" value="Hca.Common.Service.SingletonTypeCreator"/> <propertyDictionary name="Arguments" type="System.Collections.Hashtable" defaultKeyType="System.String" defaultValueType="System.Object"> <item> <key type="System.String" value="type"/> <value type="System.Type" value="Hca.Facility.CodeManagement.CodeProvider"/> </item> </propertyDictionary> </config>
Best Practices Typically, it's best to set the data values through the constructor, though there is nothing specifically wrong with setting the values through the property accessors.
Each class implements , which consists of a specialized ToString method. The format parameter can be used to specify the data elements included in the string. Each class also has standard formatting selections. See the API documentation for complete details. There are select examples below.
Date and Time
Overview in the .NET framework does not store information about the time zone. The class assumes that the time is always in the local time zone (the time zone that the machine's operating system is set). It's very possible that the time zone is not set the same on all servers in the network. Storing a date and time as Eastern or Central time can lead to confusion and mishandling.
On the other hand, when dealing with date-only values, there is no guarantee that the time values are not valued unless the developer takes care to prevent valuation. These issues result in extra code being written for each usage of , especially when dates and time are persistent.
provides four classes that work together to solve these problems: , , , and . These are found in this namespace.
Per the schema http://hcaschema.hca.corpad.net/Common/DataType/1.0/DataTypeSchema.xsd, XML serialization of these classes conform to the XSD datatypes date, time, and datetime.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.DataType.PersonName
member.summary: This class handles the elements of a person's name. Currently, it only handles basic names (first middle last) as well as prefixes (Mr., Dr., etc.) and suffixes (Jr., DDS, etc.)
member.remarks:
data elements are stored as strings and can be set and retrieved through properties. They can also be set through the overloaded constructor. If it is determined later that HCA usage required that the prefix or suffix values needs restriction, these values can be changed to a codified value. However, until this need is recognized, it is more useful to treat them as string values.
attributes include:
Prefix (Dr., Mr., etc.)
First Name, Middle Name, Last Name
Suffix (DDS, Jr., etc.)

member.name: M:Hca.Common.DataType.PersonName.ToString(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: This method provides specialized formatting of a based on the passed character(s) in the format argument.
member.remarks:
The format can be specified in two different ways.
Standard Formats
The first way is by specifying one of the "Standard Formats":
G or g (General) Default if not specified. First Last (i.e. John Smith)
N (Normal) First Middle Last (i.e. John Thomas Smith)
I (Inverted: Last Name first) Last, First Middle (i.e. Smith, John Thomas)
C (Complete) Prefix First Middle Last Suffix (i.e. Dr. John Thomas Smith III)
Custom Formats
The second way is by specifying the name segments using these identifiers.
Note: An Upper case character will display the full name segment. A Lower case for F, M and L tokens will display the initial character of the name segment followed by a period. For example, John would be J..
{P} Prefix (i.e. Dr., Mrs., Sir, etc.)
{F} First Name
{M} Middle Name
{L} Last Name
{S} Suffix (i.e. Jr., III, etc.)
Any unrecognized characters are repeated back into the output string as specified in the format string for the custom format.
If the format provided is not a standard format and none of the custom characters are recognized, the returned string is the format string as provided.
The { is treated as a delimiter of sorts and hence if you desire it to be in the output as a literal, you must escape it with a second left or right brace{ or } character. For example:
"{{F}"
will yield a parsed pattern of only the {F literal since the double left brace are consumed together. Instead, to have this appear as a brace followed by the {F} token, add a second left brace to the string. For example:
"{{{F}"
will yield a parsed pattern of a literal { followed by the F token i.e., {<F Token Value>.
Finally, to make this happen internally, we use unicode 0 and 1 as temporary replacement tokens. Hence these cannot be used as literal values in the format string. Given that these are not printable characters and this method is to generate a printable string, this is not a problem.
member.exception: Thrown if Unicode character 0 or 1 is included in the format string.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.DataType.PhoneNumber
member.summary: Phone number class provides codified properties for DeviceType and Location. Use class if you need non-codified properties. See for more detail.
member.remarks:
When a phone number is parsed or set the following attributes are not effected and must be set via the corresponding property.
location
deviceType
effectionDate
endDate
NOTES:
Extra attributes (e.g. location) are not considered when parsing
Extra attributes are not shown in the default display form.
Extra attributes are not serialized when sent to an xml stream.
Code providers should provide for the following contexts:
Location - Hca.Common.DataType.PhoneNumber.Location
DeviceType - Hca.Common.DataType.PhoneNumber.DeviceType
is associated with this type allowing two-way conversion.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.DataType.PhoneNumberBase
member.summary: This class represents a phone number. It supports both North American and International formats. See and for exact details of supported formats.
member.remarks:
is an base class for the codified and textual . is intended for use when applications have control over the data entry of codified items and . is intended for use in applications that cannot provide legal codes for these items and text values may substituted in their place.
These classes parse and validate a phone number string. They can accept the phone number segments separately or translate an alpha-numeric alias such as 1-800-Collect. They can parse North American and International numbers.
These classes will not allow an invalid phone number to be entered. Use a regular string if you must store an invalid phone number.
and share these attributes:
Country Code, Area Code, Prefix, Local Number, and Extension
Device Type (cell, fax, landline, etc.)
Alias (i.e. 1-800-FLOWERS)
Dates when it starts and stops being valid
also contains the following codified attributes:
Device Type Id (cell, fax, landline, etc.)
Location Id (home, business, etc.)
also contains the following attributes:
Device Type Text
Location Text
The semantics of properties that are not obvious is described in the Table below.
Property Semantics
Property Usage
The assigned digit(s) used to dial into a country from another country (e.g. 1 is for US and 44 is for the UK).
The part of a phone number that indicates the central office of the local number within a country. Not all countries use a prefix.
A designation for the location of the phone number (e.g., Business, Home, etc.)
The displayable text of the location ID.
A designation for the device that holds the phone number (e.g., land line, fax, cell, etc.)
The displayable text of the device type ID.
When the phone number becomes valid for use.
When the phone number becomes invalid for use.
This is not directly settable by a client but represents a textual version of the real phone number as entered when created. This is often the case for marketing purposes.
When a phone number is parsed or set the following attributes are not effected and must be set via the corresponding property.
effectionDate
endDate
NOTES:
Extra attributes (e.g. location) are not considered when parsing
Extra attributes are not shown in the default display form.
Extra attributes are not serialized when sent to an xml stream.

member.name: M:Hca.Common.DataType.PhoneNumberBase.ToString(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: This method provides specialized formatting of a based on the passed character(s) in the format argument.
member.remarks:
The format can be specified in two different ways.
Standard Formats
The first way is by specifying one of the "Standard Formats":
G or g (General)
Default if not specified. For North American phone numbers standard will be Country Code, Area Code, Prefix, and Local Number : X-XXX-XXX-XXXX International numbers will add a + to the country code which can be up to 3 digits.
N (Normal)
North American Area Code, Prefix, and Local Number : (XXX) XXX-XXXX International Country Code, Area Code, Prefix, and Local Number (the number of digits can vary and only Country code and local number are certain to be valued.
X (Normal + extension) (default if not specified) Area Code, Prefix, Local Number, and Extension : (XXX) XXX-XXXX ext. XXX
F (Full) Country Code, Area Code, Prefix, Local Number, and Extension : XXX-XXX-XXX-XXXX ext. XXX
S (Short)
North American: Prefix, and Local Number : XXX-XXXX International: Prefix if specified and Local Number.
Custom Formats
The second way is by specifying the phone number segments using these identifiers.
Note"These codes are case insensitive.
{C} Country Code without any prefix(even for international numbers)
{A} Area Code
{P} Prefix
{L} Local Number
{E} Extension
{AL} Alias, if not assigned, then the N format is used.
member.exception: Thrown if Unicode character 0 or 1 is included in the format string.
