member.summary: If , this flag indicates that this number was parsed or entered as an international number.

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.PhoneNumberBase.CountryCode
member.summary: The country code of a phone number (for example, 1 for United states of America). This is used when dialing to a foreign country but is not necessary when dialing within that country. Formats of international numbers usually include a + as a prefix to the country code (e.g. +44 for UK). This number is 3 digits in length
member.exception: Thrown if improper input values

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.PhoneNumberBase.AreaCode
member.summary: The area code or city code if international. This number is optionally surrounded by parenthesis. For North American numbers this is a three digit number (with expansion to 4 when new number format is introduced). International codes vary in length. Note: reason for string here is that we don't want to loose a zero
member.exception: Thrown if improper input values

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.PhoneNumberBase.Prefix
member.summary: The prefix (central office) of the local number. May be in countries that do not have central office concept. Note: the combination of the prefix and local number is called the subscriber number. Currently in north america this is a 3 digit number where the first digit is restricted to 2-9 digits. However, their is an industry proposal to move to a new format which is in the process of being implemented that expands this number to 4 digits with the evidential removal of the 0, 1 restriction to the old first digit. Note: reason for string here is that we don't want to loose a zero

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.PhoneNumberBase.LocalNumber
member.summary: The local (line) number. In North America this is a 4 digit number. International numbers may vary in size though no more than 12 digits. Those countries that don't have prefix needs, have this as the sole part of the subscriber number Note: reason for string here is that we don't want to loose a zero

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.PhoneNumberBase.Extension

members.member:
This class represents a specific Time Zone. It stores the information about the time offset from UTC (Universal Time Constant; aka Greenwich Mean Time) and Daylight Savings Time settings.
Functional Requirements This set of classes needs to:
Provide a date-only representation.
Provide an absolute date and time (a universally specific moment in time).
Convert a date and time between two given time zones (including UTC).
UTC is the Universal Time Constant time zone, which was previously referred to as Greenwich Mean Time.
Handle Daylight Savings Time (DST) during conversions.
Tenets The user should attempt to use values for only legitimate dates and times. Invalid values generate an error. For example, January 43, 2004 is not a valid date and 31:78AM is an invalid time.
Design
Date is a custom data type that stores the elements of a date (year, month, and day). This class does not have time elements. It is intended to be used when the developer is only concerned with the date segments of .
uses internally to validate, manipulate, and output the values. It strips out any time-specific values.
UtcDateTime is a custom data type that represents a date and time in UTC. It is intended to be used by all applications that need a timestamp so that the information is handled in a consistent manner, especially for custom data objects (Value Objects) that are passed between tiers and/or are persistent.
inherits from and extends its functionality to include the time elements. The values are always stored internally as a UTC date and time.
It also has a set of static methods that convert to and from any time zone.
TimeZoneInfo is a custom data type that represents a Time Zone. It is intended to be used by all applications that need to convert dates and times to and from time zones, including UTC. handles the standard offset from UTC as well as daylight savings time (DST).
Time zones rarely change, so it's not very likely that time zone information needs to be persistent. However, this data type can represent any time zone and could be used as a value object (e.g. a persistent data type).
also contains a pre-defined list of time zones, which are accessed with the method. This is a complete list of all time zones (2001 release). A planned future release of this class will dynamically load this data from a resource file, which is built from the data files that constitute the time zone data.
Usage and should be used in any Value Object that requires a date-only or date-time property, respectively. They should be used instead of because does not store any time zone information.
Variables typed for these classes can also be set to , indicating a not-set state. This is useful as data types for properties of any class that requires a partial update.
should be used with the static conversion methods of class to convert dates from one time zone to another.
Generally, is initialized by requesting one of its pre-defined time zones. If a time zone is requested that does not exist in this list, then code throws an exception.
Exceptions are also thrown when or instances are initialized with invalid dates and/or times.
Use or instead of .NET's .
Best Practices Use and as data types for properties of Value Objects instead of . Additionally, when only a date is needed (such as representing a date of birth), use since it ensures that time components are not valued. Similarly, if you need to represent something like a status time or change date, use .
TimeZoneInfo timezone = TimeZoneInfo.GetTimeZoneInfo(TimeZoneInfo.CommonTimeZoneCode.EST); UtcDateTime utc = new UtcDateTime(2004,2,14,8,45,0,0); DateTime eastern = UtcDateTime.ConvertFromUtc(utc, timezone);
TimeZoneInfo timezone = TimeZoneInfo.GetTimeZoneInfo(TimeZoneInfo.CommonTimeZoneCode.EST); TimeZoneInfo info = TimeZoneInfo.GetTimeZoneInfo(TimeZoneInfo.CommonTimeZoneNames.AmericaPacificStandardTime); TimeZoneInfo info = TimeZoneInfo.GetTimeZoneInfo("Europe/Madrid");

If = 0 then the day of the month that DST starts. If > 0 then the 1st, 2nd, last, etc. Day of Week in the month. If < 0 then DST starts on the on, before, or after this day of the month. Zero indicates No Daylight Saving Time. (see the property summary)

Zero indicates DST starts on a specific day of the month. Greater than Zero indicates the day of the week that DST starts (values 1 to 7). Less than Zero indicates DST starts on this day of the week before, after, or on the day of the month (values -1 to -7). (see the and property summaries)
The time of day that DST starts (in milliseconds).

If = 0 then the day of the month that DST ends. If > 0 then the 1st, 2nd, last, etc. Day of Week in the month. If < 0 then DST ends on the on, before, or after this day of the month. Zero indicates No Daylight Saving Time. (see the property summary)

Zero indicates DST ends on a specific day of the month. Greater than Zero indicates the day of the week that DST ends (values 1 to 7). Less than Zero indicates DST ends on this day of the week before, after, or on the day of the month (values -1 to -7). (see the and property summaries)
The time of day that DST ends (in milliseconds).

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.TimeZoneInfo.Offset
member.summary: The number of milliseconds to add or subtract from UTC for this .

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.TimeZoneInfo.Id
member.summary: The identifier for this .

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.TimeZoneInfo.StartMode
member.summary: The method this uses to determine when DST starts.

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.TimeZoneInfo.StartMonth
member.summary: The month this starts DST.

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.TimeZoneInfo.StartDay
member.summary:
This field has two possible meanings: 1. If = then this is the 1st, 2nd, etc. day of week in the month (valid values are: -5 to 5)
2. If != then this is the day that DST starts on, before, or after (valid values are: 1 to 28,30, or 31)
member.remarks:
Example:
StartMode = DayOfMonth StartMonth = March StartDay = 16
DST starts on March 16.
Example:
StartMode = DayOfWeekInMonth StartDayOfWeek = Sunday StartMonth = March
If StartDay = 2 then DST starts on the 2nd Sunday in March
If StartDay = -1 then DST starts on the last Sunday in March
Example:
StartMode = DayOfWeekAfterDayOfMonth StartDayOfWeek = Sunday StartMonth = March StartDay = 16
DST starts on the first Sunday on or after March 16.
Example:
StartMode = DayOfWeekBeforeDayOfMonth StartDayOfWeek = Sunday StartMonth = March StartDay = 16
DST starts on the first Sunday on or before March 16.

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.TimeZoneInfo.StartDayOfWeek
member.summary: The Day of Week this starts DST.

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.TimeZoneInfo.StartTime
member.summary: The time of day this starts DST (in milliseconds).

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.TimeZoneInfo.StartTimeMode
member.summary: The time mode (WALL, STANDARD, UTC) this starts DST.

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.TimeZoneInfo.EndMode
member.summary: The method this uses to determine when DST ends.

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.TimeZoneInfo.EndMonth
member.summary: The month this ends DST.

member.name: P:Hca.Common.DataType.TimeZoneInfo.EndDay
member.summary:
This field has two possible meanings: 1. If = then this is the 1st, 2nd, etc. day of week in the month (valid values are: -5 to 5)
2. If != then this is the day that DST ends on, before, or after (valid values are: 1 to 28,30, or 31)
member.remarks:
Example:
EndMode = DayOfMonth EndMonth = October EndDay = 16
DST ends on October 16.
Example:
EndMode = DayOfWeekInMonth EndDayOfWeek = Sunday EndMonth = October
If EndDay = 2 then DST ends on the 2nd Sunday in October
If EndDay = -1 then DST ends on the last Sunday in October
Example:
EndMode = DayOfWeekAfterDayOfMonth EndDayOfWeek = Sunday EndMonth = October EndDay = 16
DST ends on the first Sunday on or after October 16.
Example:
EndMode = DayOfWeekBeforeDayOfMonth EndDayOfWeek = Sunday EndMonth = October EndDay = 16
DST ends on the first Sunday on or before October 16.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.DataType.UtcDateTime
member.summary: This class represents a time in Universal Time Coordinated (UTC).
member.remarks:
This means any value set without explicitly indicating that it is a local time will be treated as UTC. For example, when we are on Daylight Savings Time (DST), the offset of local to UTC in the central timezone is -6 hours. When using this class with XML serialization, note that the time shown is also in UTC. Hence, if you want to show the time as local time, you must covert it yourself. In addition, the fractional seconds are included since to keep the type in tack, it must be included. However, the precision of these fractional seconds is set such that this type is useful when storing datetimes in a database. Since SqlServer precision is only down to 3.33 milliseconds, we chose this as our default precision. If you desire another precision, choose one of the other available value in the Enum and pass that into the constructor so that values will be kept at the correct resolution. Note that any method which adds or subtracts milliseconds or ticks may result in zero being added or subtracted given the value presented is less than the current precision. When creating a new instance of this class via the default Constructor or through an existing time, if the time for existing time values is , the current Utc time is used with the default precision.
Functional Requirements This class needs to:
Provide an absolute date and time (a universally specific moment in time).
Convert a date and time between two given time zones (including UTC).
UTC is the Universal Time Constant time zone, which was previously referred to as Greenwich Mean Time.
Handle Daylight Savings Time (DST) during conversions.
Tenets The user should attempt to use values for only legitimate dates and times. Invalid values generate an error. For example, January 43, 2004 is not a valid date and 31:78AM is an invalid time.
Design is a custom data type that represents a date and time in UTC. It is intended to be used by all applications that need a timestamp so that the information is handled in a consistent manner, especially for custom data objects (Value Objects) that are passed between tiers and/or are persistent.
inherits from and extends its functionality to include the time elements. The values are always stored internally as a UTC date and time.
It also has a set of static methods that convert to and from any time zone.
Usage should be used in any Value Object that requires a date-time property. This should be used instead of because does not store any time zone information.
Variables typed for this can also be set to , indicating a not-set state. This is useful as data types for properties of any class that requires a partial update.
Generally, is initialized by requesting one of its pre-defined time zones. If a time zone is requested that does not exist in this list, then code throws an exception.
Exceptions are also thrown when instances are initialized with invalid dates and/or times.
Use instead of .NET's .
Best Practices Use as a data type for properties of Value Objects instead of . Additionally, if you need to represent something like a status time or change date, use .
is associated with this type allowing two-way conversion.

hcaExample.desc: Example 12: Setting the values through the constructor - individual values
hcaExample.code: // Feb 14, 2004 at 8:45 AM UtcDateTime utc = new UtcDateTime(2004,2,14,8,45,0,0);

member.summary: Gets the Offset in milliseconds from UTC time for the specified date in the specified timezone. The offset is adjusted for daylight savings time. This is the offset to add TO UTC to get local time. To convert local time to UTC time, subtract this offset from the local time.
member.remarks: There was a validation section in this method in a previous version of this class, but I removed it since we are passing in a valid date, now, instead of a list of date elements (year, month, etc.).
member.param: The date-time to find the offset for.
The timezone that the date is specified in.
member.returns: The offset in milliseconds to add TO UTC time.

member.summary: Compare a given date in the year to a rule. Return 1, 0, or -1, depending on whether the date is after, equal to, or before the rule date. The millis are compared directly against the , so any standard-daylight adjustments must be handled by the caller.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Logger.ForcedLogger
member.summary: Provides the capability to override a logger's configured level.
member.remarks:
Loggers are configured to log at a certain level and higher. This configuration is usually in a config file. At times, especially during unit testing, it may be convenient to override a default log setting. This class supports forcing a logger to a level remembering its original level.
This class is a disposable class so it may be used in a using statement.

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Logger.ForcedLogger.#ctor(System.String)

member.param: The name of the logger to toggle.

member.summary: Constructor that takes the name of the logger to toggle and a flag to turn on debugging.
member.param: The name of the logger to toggle.
if debug should be turned on. will restore the original level.

member.summary: Turn debug on or off

member.summary: Dispose

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Logger.HcaLogger
member.summary: This class is the logger that should be used in all situations. It is a wrapper around the actual logging framework.

remarks.p: This class is the logger that should be used for all classes. It wraps the actual logging framework. This is a wrapper delegating the calls to the lower logging framework. It allows a consistent method to invoke logging while allowing the capability to change out the actual implementation at a later time. At this time the framework wraps Log4net, .
The severity of logging level is the following: , , , , . So, if you set the severity to WARN, then only FATAL, ERROR, and WARN messages will be logged.
By default, all objects passed to the logger will have their ToString() called unless a specific object renderer has been defined for that object type.
You should configure the logger with a file ending in HcaDevBlockCommon.dll.log4net in the app domain's base directory. The logger will configure itself and watch the file for any changes.
If you need to interleave log messages based on context, then see log4net's NDC.

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Logger.HcaLogger.ConfigureLoggingSystem
member.summary: Configure logging system.
member.remarks: This method will first check and see if a configuration setting is available with a key of Hca.Common.Logger.LogConfigurationFile. If found, then its value is used to indicate the path and file name for the configuration file. Otherwise, it will look for a file in AppDomain's base directory that ends in logging.config. If it does not find one, then a basic configuration will be setup that outputs to the console only.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Logger.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
Overview Logging is an essential software component that provides important diagnostic information to both application authors and system administrators. This section describes the requirements that shaped the design and implementation of the logging component located in the namespace.
HCA logging uses Log4Net to implement logging functionality. Log4Net contains in-depth documentation on configuration and usage. This information is not duplicated here. For more information about Log4Net, refer to the Log4Net documentation on their website.
References The following works are referenced in this SDK:
Table 1: Referenced Works
Label Title Reference
LOG4NET Log4Net Website
(future)
FAQ Log4Net FAQ
LOG4J Log4J Website
APPENDERS Log4Net Appenders Examples
BARETAIL BareTail software
TEXTPAD TextPad software
CYGWIN CYGWIN software
Requirements The following requirements describe the constraints and functional needs placed on Logging:
Logging statements should reside in deployed code without adversely effecting the application.
It should support multiple logging sources and output sinks.
It should allow selective control of output with arbitrary granularity.
It should be easy to configure and be able to reconfigure at runtime.
It should provide a logging context to handle interleaving log sources.
It should wrap as best it can the underlying logging implementation decoupling it from the calling system.
Tenets Users of the framework should adhere to the following items:
Use a RollingFileAppender to log output for developer's purposes. By default, no logging should be occurring within production. Don't forget that your web application must have rights to write to this directory which by default is Log.
Use TraceAppender to log output to Visual Studio's Output window.
All system exceptions should be logged. Logging of Application Exceptions is dependent on the application's design.
Debug statements should first check that debug is enabled in situations where performance is crucial. This ensures that the log string is not needlessly constructed.
Do not configure the logger through an application or web configuration file by using Log4Net's configuration mechanism but use the configuration techniques provided by this component. This means the configuration of the logging system is through a file located at the application domain's base directory or through a configuration setting in the application or web config file.
An application configuration file is an applicationname.exe.config file where a web configuration file is web.config. These files are used by the applications to abstract out configuration information.
The default production setup should be as follows. Keep in mind that the logging configuration file can be edited in production to assist with problem resolution.
Applications should log only and higher events to a RollingFileAppender.
Events of types and should be the only events logged to the EventLogAppender. This allows BSSC to monitor the application and open trouble tickets for the application stating the description of the log message. The levels are used to set ticket severity levels.
Design HCA Logger consists of one component that wraps the underlying logging framework. This design was chosen to insulate applications, frameworks, and class libraries from being coupled to any specific logging framework. This is especially important since loggers are used throughout most classes and coupling to any logging framework would require massive code changes.
HcaLogger This class defines each of the following log levels: Table 2: Logging Levels
Level Purpose
Diagnostic logging
Communicate information logging
Indicates a potential problem
Indicates a potential severe problem or bad data
Indicates that the application is broken
Each log event has a log level. The levels are used to filter log events for each appender. An appender is a logging sink that consumes log events. An appender defines what range of log level events it consumes and the format of its output. wraps [log4net], a logger ported from [log4j]. Log4j has been ported to 12 languages and is considered the premier logging system for applications and frameworks. It is a hierarchical logging system that makes it an ideal design for component-based development, allowing each component to have its own logger. This fine grain control allows selective output of logging events. It supports easy configuration through a XML file or direct programmatic control. Finally, it can collect logging context data and attach it to log messages.
You configure the logging framework through a XML file found with the Common Framework DLL or you can add a configuration setting indicating the location of this file. If a configuration file is not found, the logger will output a message to and , indicating that the logger was not configured. If the file is found, then it is digested and watched for any future changes. This allows you to modify the logger at runtime.
Usage This section describes the configuration of HCA logger and its typical usage.
Configuration HCA logger looks for a file named logging.config. This file should reside with the Common DLL or an application/web configuration setting should be made which indicates the location of this file (see example 1 below). If an application/web configuration setting is used, then the configuration file may have any name. The logging file is the configuration file used to configure Log4Net and subsequently HCA Logger (see example 2 below).
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="Hca.Common.Logger.LogConfigurationFile" value="E:\net-projects\SBBCommon\LogExample\logging.config"/> </appSettings> </configuration>
Following is an example from the DevPack templates of the default logging configuration for production.
<?xml version="1.0" ?> <log4net threshold="ALL"> <appender name="AppRollingFileAppender" type="log4net.Appender.RollingFileAppender"> <param name="Threshold" value="ALL"/> <param name="File" value="Log\\log-file.txt" /> <param name="AppendToFile" value="true" /> <param name="MaxSizeRollBackups" value="-1" /> <param name="RollingStyle" value="Date" /> <param name="StaticLogFileName" value="true" /> <param name="CountDirection" value="-1" /> <param name="DatePattern" value="yyyyMMdd" /> <layout type="log4net.Layout.PatternLayout"> <param name="ConversionPattern" value="%date [%level] %property{log4net:HostName} (%thread) %logger [%ndc] - %message%newline" /> </layout> </appender>
<!-- Event Appenders --> <appender name="AppEventLogAppender" type="log4net.Appender.EventLogAppender"> <param name="Threshold" value="ERROR"/> <param name="LogName" value="zMonitor"/> <param name="ApplicationName" value="@project.short.name@"/> <layout type="log4net.Layout.PatternLayout"> <param name="ConversionPattern" value="DevBlocks : %date [%level] %property{log4net:HostName} (%thread) %logger [%ndc] - %.1200message%newline" /> </layout> </appender>
<!-- Application Sink loggers --> <root> <appender-ref ref="AppRollingFileAppender" /> <appender-ref ref="AppEventLogAppender"/> </root>
<!-- DevBlocks Sink loggers --> <logger name="Hca.Common"> <level value="ERROR" /> </logger> <logger name="Hca.Framework"> <level value="ERROR" /> </logger> <logger name="Hca.Facility"> <level value="ERROR" /> </logger> </log4net>
This file can serve as a good introduction to the structure of a logging configuration file. It is basically the bare minimum necessary to configure production logging. It includes two appenders, a RollingFileAppender and an EventLogAppender. Additionally, it includes several event sinks.
The RollingFileAppender is configured to accept events of any type. The events are filtered at another location that will be discussed shortly. Currently, it writes its events to a file name log-file.txt in a folder named Log at the application root. At production deployment time, you should include a build step to change this value to the appropriate logging location for the environment. Consult WinTel deployment procedures for more information.
The EventLogAppender is configured to accept events only of type or . It writes them to a special Windows Event Log named zMonitor. This event log is monitored by devices that will open trouble tickets for the application with the event message. The value of the ApplicationName is configurable for your application. It is the value that will appear in the Windows Event Log source and is the value by which the monitoring tool uses to deliver the trouble ticket.
The root element is the default configuration for event log sinks. This element is required by log4net. The current configuration filters events only to those of type and higher and forwards those to both the RollingFileAppender and the EventLogAppender. Again, for this example, those appenders then filter based on their rules. The RollingFileAppender will log anything that comes to it, and the EventLogAppender will only log or events.
The individual logger elements are used to impose additional filtering limitations on DevBlocks, as they will use this logging configuration as well. This is also a feature that you can customize for your purposes if you need to set different filtering levels for different namespaces in your solution.
Further Examples
<?xml version="1.0" ?> <log4net> <!-- Define some output appenders --> <appender name="ConsoleAppender" type="log4net.Appender.ConsoleAppender"> <layout type="log4net.Layout.PatternLayout"> <param name="ConversionPattern" value="%d [%t] %-5p [%c{1}] [%x] <%X{auth}> - %m%n" /> </layout> </appender> <appender name="TraceAppender" type="log4net.Appender.TraceAppender"> <layout type="log4net.Layout.PatternLayout"> <param name="ConversionPattern" value="%d [%t] %-5p [%c{1}] [%x] <%X{auth}> - %m%n" /> </layout> </appender>
<!-- Setup the root category, add the appenders and set the default level --> <root> <level value="WARN" /> <appender-ref ref="ConsoleAppender" /> <appender-ref ref="TraceAppender" /> </root>
<!-- Specify the level for some specific categories --> <logger name="Hca"> <level value="ALL" /> </logger> <logger name="Hca.MyApp.Web"> <level value="ERROR" /> </logger> <logger name="Hca.MyApp.SomeService"> <level value="WARN" /> </logger> </log4net>
Some highlights from this configuration file include:
Two appenders defined - Console and Trace. These communicate to the console and trace output. Trace is used to see output within Visual Studio's output screen.
TRACE constant must be defined as a conditional compilation constant for your project to see output.
For both appenders, the log output pattern will produce the following output:
2004-01-19 08:06:32,274 [STATestRunner] INFO [HcaLogger] [] <> - message.
Two special loggers are defined to customize the logging for "MyApp". Class is the Hca.MyApp.Web namespace will only write events of type and higher. Whereas classes in the namespace Hca.MyApp.SomeService write events of type and higher.
For more information on log output pattern, see Log4Net API for PatternLayout class. For a more complete logging configuration file, see the logging.config supplied in the distribution file for .
Best Practices Logging is an essential part of any application, framework, or class library. It provides important diagnostic information to the user and developer. Determining what to see and where to output the log events is normally the most difficult part in logging and determined by the needs of developers and system administrators. It is important to log as much diagnostic information as possible.
Configuration The best practice for the logger configuration includes:
Determine what appenders need to be defined. [Appenders] are log events sinks. Log4net comes with many out-of-the-box appenders and the ability to define new ones.
Define the root logger.
Define any application-level loggers.
Refer to the documentation for any other DevBlocks that you consume. They may have additional logging configuration requirements.
Defining a Logger Typically, a logger is defined for each class. The logger is named with the class' fully qualified name. This allows fine-grain control over what is and is not logged to appenders. If you would like to use a logger that represents a tier or a component that covers a set of classes, then define it with an appropriate name.
public class Class1 { private static readonly HcaLogger log = HcaLogger.GetLogger(typeof(Class1));
#region other things // ... #endregion }
Using a Logger Once a logger is defined, it can now be used to output diagnostic information.
log.Debug("A debug message.");
will ensure debugging is enabled before logging debug messages, so under normal usage it is not necessary to check that debugging is enabled before usage. However, if a series of operations need to be performed for logging, it is recommended to wrap those operations in a conditional branch.
if(log.IsDebugEnabled) { StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(); sb.Append("This is some simple debugging"); sb.Append(System.Environment.NewLine); sb.Append("This is some more simple debugging information."); log.Debug(sb.ToString()); }
Rolling File Logging This appender provides an array of settings, making it very attractive to use as a production appender. The following sample differs from the recommended setup, but is expanded and documented as a demonstration of capabilities:
<appender name="RollingFileAppender" type="log4net.Appender.RollingFileAppender"> <param name="Threshold" value="ALL"/> <param name="File" value="Log\\MyApp.log" /> <param name="AppendToFile" value="true" />
<!-- An alternate output encoding can be specified --> <!-- <param name="Encoding" value="unicodeFFFE" /> -->
<!-- keep 10 backups before erasing oldest --> <param name="MaxSizeRollBackups" value="10" />
<!-- maximum file size is 100 MB--> <param name="MaximumFileSize" value="100MB" /> <!-- roll based on date then size --> <param name="RollingStyle" value="Date"/>
<!-- We do want to log to the same file. --> <param name="StaticLogFileName" value="false" />
<!-- Recommended for infinite backups. It means that the higher number is the latest log. --> <param name="CountDirection" value="-1" />
<!-- This is the default date pattern. This means the roll point would be by day. --> <param name="DatePattern" value="yyyyMMdd" /> <layout type="log4net.Layout.PatternLayout"> <param name="ConversionPattern" value="%d [%t] %-5p [%c{1}] [%x] <%X{auth}> - %m%n" /> </layout> </appender>
Highlights from this setup include:
The appender will append its log output to the current log file.
Only 10 backups will be kept after that the oldest backups will be removed.
The maximum size for a backup file is 100MB.
Backups will be rolled based on the date.
The appender will log to the current date log file.
The date pattern to use and subsequent determination to roll by date is YYYYMMdd.
Tailing a Log File If you want to watch a log file for diagnostic purposes, it is helpful to view the log file with a tool that does not lock the file and outputs the file as it changes. This is often referred to as tailing the log. Several tools can be used to tail a log. One is the shareware tool [TEXTPAD]. TextPad informs you if the file changes, allowing you to refresh the file and look at the current contents. However, a better method is to use a true tail program such as [BARETAIL]. This is a Windows specific tail tool. Here is a sample look at tailing a log with BareTail.
Figure 1: Tailing a File with BareTail
A final tool that might be used to tail a log file is [CYGWIN]. This is a UNIX emulating tool. By default, UNIX provides a tail program so users using CYGWIN can just use the built-in tail program.
Figure 2: Tailing a File with Cygwin
Logging to the Windows Event System The Windows Event System is used to send application events. These events are sent to an application source setup in the event system. The application source must be setup by a user with administrative privileges. The package release of DevPack or ServerPack provides a console EXE that will create an application event source. Administrative personnel can run this EXE to create application event sources. Refer to those distributions for more information. Also, remember that the recommended setup for production is to only log events to the custom event log zMonitor. If your solution requires your own event log for other purposes, this will likely require additional documentation and approvals.
C:\Program Files\HCA\DevPack\EventSourceBuilder>eventsourcebuilder Purpose: Create or delete an event source and / or event log on the current machine. Usage: EventSourceBuilder.exe [ [/l | /dl] log ] [ [/s | /ds | /qs] source ] [ /t message] Options: /l log Append or create an event log. Must be used in conjunction with /s. /dl log Delete an event log and all registered sources. /s source Create event source. /ds source Delete event source. /qs source Query event source registration. /t message Write test message to the event source. Must be used in conjunction with /s or /qs. Examples: > EventSourceBuilder /l NewLogName /s NewSourceName > EventSourceBuilder /l NewLogName /s NewSourceName /t "hello world!" > EventSourceBuilder /ds DeleteSourceName > EventSourceBuilder /dl DeleteLogName > EventSourceBuilder /qs QuerySourceName
After setting up an application event source, the EventLogAppender can now log to it.
<appender name="EventLogAppender" type="log4net.Appender.EventLogAppender"> <!-- Only allow WARN and higher levels to be logged --> <param name="Threshold" value="WARN"/> <layout type="log4net.Layout.PatternLayout"> <param name="ConversionPattern" value="%d [%t] %-5p [%c{1}] [%x] <%X{auth}> - %m%n" /> </layout> </appender>
Notice in the configuration of the EventLogAppender, that a threshold of was used indicating that only and higher event levels will be logged. The event log should not be used to output DEBUG or INFO levels. A file log is a better source for these events.
Let's say your application has a project short name of Hca.DevBlocks.Common and you want to send all or higher events to the application event log.
Project short name refers to the build property that is equivalent to the application's DLL name.
To set this up you can use the EventSourceBuilder.exe and type in the following:
eventsourcebuilder /l zMonitor /s Common
Remember that you need administrator privileges. This will create an event source in the zMonitor log. Your logging configuration defined through DevPack will provide you with an EventLogAppender setup to log to zMonitor and source project short name.
Don't forget that you need to repeat the event log setup for all environments DEV, QA, PROD.
The Event Logging system only considers the first eight characters of the event log sink for uniqueness. Keep that in mind as you provide the sink name.
Logging to ASPNET Trace ASP.NET allows developers to write out diagnostic information to the ASP page.
ASP.NET Header In order to output to an ASP.NET page, a page directive must be set or the web.config trace for all ASP.NET pages needs to be turned on. You can view the output of the ASP.NET trace by browsing to your applications URI with 'trace.axd'. For instance, if you application is deployed locally and named 'petstore' then you can view the trace output by browsing to 'http://localhost/petstore/trace.axd'.
<%@ Page language="c#" Codebehind="WebForm1.aspx.cs" AutoEventWireup="false" Inherits="DevBlocksTesting.WebForm1" trace="True">
In order to output to ASP.NET trace, an ASP.NET appender must be defined in the logging configuration file.
<appender name="ASPNetTraceAppender" type="log4net.Appender.ASPNetTraceAppender" > <layout type="log4net.Layout.PatternLayout"> <param name="ConversionPattern" value="%d [%t] %-5p %c [%x] - %m%n" /> </layout> </appender> <appender name="ASPNetTraceAppender" type="log4net.Appender.ASPNetTraceAppender" > <layout type="log4net.Layout.PatternLayout"> <param name="ConversionPattern" value="%d [%t] %-5p %c [%x] - %m%n" /> </layout> </appender>
private void Button1_Click(object sender, System.EventArgs e) { HcaLogger log = HcaLogger.GetLogger(System.Reflection.MethodBase.GetCurrentMethod().DeclaringType); log.Debug("Message is logged."); log.Debug("Next message."); Class1 test = new Class1(); test.test(); log.Debug("Next message2."); }
Figure 3: ASP.NET Trace Output
Forced Debug Logging Loggers are typically configured through a log configuration file. This file defines the levels for specified loggers including defining log appenders. Log levels are hierarchical, ranging from ALL, TRACE, , , , , CRITICAL, and FATAL. Loggers may be explicitly or implicitly defined for a particular level through the hierarchy of another logger. At least one logger - ROOT logger - has a level defined. Applications define the log levels its loggers should write output for consuming appenders. Though not normal, there are occasions that an application's logger's particular defined level should be overwritten and forced to a level. Normally, you should modify the configuration file.
HCA logger is able to override a log's level configuration and force the logger's level to . The override retains the original level, allowing you to restore it later.
HcaLogger.ForcedDebugOn(typeof(HashCodeGenerator)); int hash1 = HashCodeGenerator.CalculateHashCode(ATrain1); log.Debug("++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++"); int hash2 = HashCodeGenerator.CalculateHashCode(ATrain2); HcaLogger.ForcedDebugOff(typeof(HashCodeGenerator));
using (HcaLogger.ForcedDebugOn(typeof(ValueComparator))) { bool isEqual1 = ValueComparator.IsEqual(passTrain1, passTrain2); Assert.IsTrue(isEqual1, "The TestClassWithReciprocalRelationships test #1 was not true"); }

The main purpose of this class is to be used by Value Objects (user-defined data classes) that have a 'value type' property which needs a "Not Set" state (). There is no need to use this class for an variable or property that will always have a legitimate value.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Resource.HcaResourceManager
member.summary: A singleton class that wraps a and associates it with a default Resource store.

remarks.para: The resource-access semantics provided by this class are identical to those of the HCA .
The inner is configured using the entries in the null configuration context. (For more information on the configuration store, see the namespace.)

The singleton object is instantiated lazily, that is, the class' configuration will not be loaded until the first request to get . The advantage is that no processing will be wasted loading its configuration if it is never used. However, the side-effect is that the first request for the will be more expensive than those following.

example.para: For example .config file XML syntax, please see .
For an example of usage, please see .

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Resource.IResourceHelper
member.summary: An interface that furnishes access to string resources.

remarks.para: This interface exists primarily to enforce similar access signatures for HcaResourceManagers and .

A request for a resource must be confined to a given context (a named set of resources) and may be localized per culture (if available). Additionally, any replaceable parameters in the string resource can be populated along with the request.
By default, if the request fails (the named resource is not found), the call will throw an exception. This can be disabled, however, in which case the caller will receive as a return value.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Resource.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: Overview Application code almost always needs string resources, for exception messages if not for the User Interface. A Resource Manager cleanly separates the executable code from the resources on which it depends. This separation clarifies design and development, eases maintenance, and enables enterprise-required features such as language and locale sensitivity. This section describes the requirements that shaped the design and implementation of the , , and in the namespace. References The following works are referenced in this SDK: Table 1: Referenced Works Label Title Reference MsNetResource .NET Framework Developer's Guide: Resources in Applications MsNetFormat .NET Framework Developer's Guide: Formatting Types ConfigUsage Configuration SDK HCA Dev Block Common - SDK ExcFrmUsage Exception Framework SDK HCA Dev Block Common - SDK MsNetPatterns Enterprise Solution Patterns Using Microsoft .NET MsNetClasses .NET Framework Class Library Requirements The classes in the namespace provide the basic resource management functionality (code/resource separation and language/locale customization) that .NET's or Java's ResourceBundle provides, with the following additional features: Declarative configuration and singleton (see [MsNetPatterns], chapter 5) instantiation. This puts resources at the developer's fingertips using a familiar XML schema. In-call formatting of replaceable parameters. Contextual grouping of resources avoids name collisions in the singleton's (potentially very large) resource set. Application-level override of libraries' resource configuration - allows declarative customization of any resources used by a referenced library. Multi-instance helper class for special cases where the singleton isn't ideal. Tenets The following guidelines should be observed by developers using the classes: Any string that is intended for reading by a human at run-time is a good candidate resource. Direct usage of a should be reserved only for special cases where using a (which inherently calls ) is clearly contra-indicated. Use of classes within the framework are context sensitive. Resources' string names should not be hard coded throughout the application. Use of classes alleviate this concern. (See [ExcFrmUsage] for details.) Document the names and uses of your embedded resources for easy override by consumers of your code. The recommended method is a well-commented extension of the class. For this reason, direct usage of the is often not needed. Design The following class diagram illustrates the relationships between the classes in the Resource namespace. Image 1: Resource Class Diagram IResourceHelper This interface defines common resource-retrieval semantics for the classes in the namespace. ResourceHelper The is the primary implementation of . It is initialized using an array of objects and internally constructs a list of named contexts. Each context, in turn, has a list of resources associated with it. The handles localization automatically. It looks first for a resource localized for the specific culture requested. If this is not found, less specific cultures are successively searched (down to the default culture-neutral resource) until a match is found. (For details, see [MsNetResource].) The can also format replaceable parameters inline. This is enabled by the development platform. (For details, see [MsNetFormat].) When a call is received, the first resource in the specific context that matches the passed context name is returned. Thus, resource-name collision actually enables the override functionality in the requirements. HcaResourceManager The also implements . It wraps an inner in a singleton for consistent, convenient access and loads its own settings directly from the null configuration context in the configuration store. The singleton object is instantiated lazily. ResourceConfig The idea of wrapping an entire resource context in a single configuration object was not used in order to keep the XML as straightforward as possible. However, the concept of a context is expressed as multiple ResourceConfigs with matching properties. The resource context of a given object (specified using the property on ) should not be confused with config's context (specified using the context attribute on the config XML element). (See [ConfigUsage] for details on configuration contexts.) ResourceMessage This class provide encapsulation of the context, arguments, and behavior around retrieving a message from a resource. uses in its method for retrieving resources. Use of is recommended as opposed to direct usage of . Usage This section describes the configuration of and for use with . It describes best practices for resource developers of applications consuming these components. Configuration An array of objects is used to initialize a . This array can be either programmatically constructed or declaratively defined using 's configuration functionality. (See the section.) The initializes its instance using declared configuration in the null configuration context. Declarative configuration will look something like the following: All of the properties are required. is the resource context (in the ) in which to place the resources described by this . ResourceConfigs, with matching ContextNames, instruct the to group the resources together in one resource context. Overlapping resource names within a context are resolved on a first-in basis. is the assembly in which to search for . The value given should be in the format required by System.Reflection.Assembly.Load(string assemblyString). (See [MsNetClasses].) Strong assembly names must be specified for any resource that is embedded in an assembly that resides in the .NET Global Assembly Cache: ResourceExample, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089) is the name of the embedded .resources file to look for in the assembly specified by . (See [MsNetResource].) In this example, the ResourceExample assembly (presumably the application's primary assembly) contains two .resources files: messages.resources, and exceptions.resources. The Hca.DevBlocks.Common assembly contains one .resources file: Hca.Common.BaseException.EmbedResource.commonexcmsg (..resources). Two contexts are created within the at run-time. The first, message, contains the resources from messages.resources. The second, exception, contains all the resources from exceptions.resources and all the resources from Hcaresources. If messages.resources contains a resource with the same name as a resource in Hca.resources, then the resource in messages.resources overrides the resource in Com.resources. Best Practices General usage of these components is fairly forthright. A few guidelines should keep consumers' experience optimal. Any string that is intended for reading by a human at run-time is a good candidate resource In other words, it should be used. Hard-coded strings make code brittle. For example: Console.WriteLine("The operation succeeded."); string resourceContext = "message"; ... public static MyAppResourceMessage SuccessMessage() { return new MyAppResourceMessage(resourceContext, "SuccessMessage"); } ... Console.WriteLine(MyAppResourceMessage.SuccessMessage()); SuccessMsg=The operation succeeded. SuccessMsg=La operacin tenida xito. SuccessMsg=L'opration a russi. And if the verbiage ever needs to change from 'operation' to 'action', the code never needs to be touched. Note that users do not have to use name/value pair format .txt files. The .NET compiler will compile both .txt and xml .resx files into the correct .resources format. Create a custom class that derives from for accessing resource messages It is the responsibility of the developer to implement access to resources for their application. Hard-coding resource name strings throughout code is error-prone and complicates maintenance, especially when a resource is referenced by code in multiple locations. We recommend that static methods for those names are defined in a resource message class named ResourceMessage.cs which derives from . This strongly types all references to the resource, enabling intellisense and eliminating the possibility of spelling mistakes. In the odd case when a resource gets renamed, changes to the code are minimized. For a practical example of this, see BaseException.ExceptionMessage or the examples below. derives from , both of which use a to obtain its resources when the is implicitly converted to a string. Direct usage of a should be reserved only for special cases where using a is clearly contra-indicated is designed to handle the vast majority of consumers' resource-retrieval needs. It should be used for all but the most exceptional usage scenarios. However, some circumstances may require direct interaction with a . Such scenarios could include the following requirements: Imperative configuration: the used by loads its own configuration from the declarative configuration file; will take whatever configuration is passed to its constructor. More direct control over the time at which resource assemblies are loaded. By default, the loads all declared resource assemblies together. Resources must always be defined within a specific context In the vast majority of cases (especially when using the ), many contexts are defined and numerous library resources are present. Cross-context resource searches would take much more time and might yield unexpected results if context names overlap. For this reason requests are required to specify a contextName. Document the names and uses of your embedded resources for easy override by consumers of your code A key feature of the is that the rules for priority used when there are resource-name collisions allow for powerful overriding customizations in an application for messages generated by referenced libraries. However, this only works if the resources used by the referenced libraries are clearly and thoroughly documented for the developers of the applications. Begin by listing the contexts and names by which a library's resources are organized. Then, for each resource, describe briefly when, where, and how that string appears in the application's output. Examples The MyClass.cs code that follows consumes the resources defined in the following files: SuccessMessage=The operation succeeded. [{0}] SuccessMessage=La operacin tenida xito. [{0}] SuccessMessage=L'opration a russi. [{0}] using System; using System.Globalization; using System.Threading; using Hca.Common.Resource; namespace ResourceExample { class MyClass { [STAThread] static void Main(string[] args) { try { CultureInfo[] cultures = new CultureInfo[] { CultureInfo.CreateSpecificCulture("es"), CultureInfo.CreateSpecificCulture("fr"), CultureInfo.CreateSpecificCulture("en") }; Random randomGenerator = new Random(); int whichCulture = randomGenerator.Next(3); Console.WriteLine(cultures[whichCulture].ToString()); Thread.CurrentThread.CurrentUICulture = cultures[whichCulture]; Thread.Sleep(1000); Console.WriteLine(MyClassResourceMessage.SuccessMessage("1000")); } finally { Console.ReadLine(); } } } } using System; using System.Globalization; using System.Threading; using Hca.Common.Resource; namespace ResourceExample { public sealed class MyAppResourceMessage : ResourceMessage { private static string resourceContext = "MyAppContext"; /// /// Create a resource message from the given a name and some replaceable arguments. /// /// The name used within the resource to retrieve. /// Arguments to be placed into the message in sequential order. public MyAppResourceMessage (string name, params object[] formatArgs) : base(resourceContext, name, formatArgs) { } /// /// Used when an operation completed successfully. /// Message: "The operation succeeded. [{0}]" /// /// Some description of the argument goes here. public static MyAppResourceMessage SuccessMessage(string arg) { return new MyAppResourceMessage(MethodBase.GetCurrentMethod().Name, arg); } } } In the above scenario, the first few lines in Main() choose a culture for the User Interface. Spanish ("es") and French ("fr") have special resources defined for them. English ("en"), on the other hand, does not, and uses the default resource that's compiled with the code (which in this case, happens to be English.) The placeholder in the resources string ("{0}") is populated with the first (and only) member of the array passed to . So the output of this program will resemble the following: E:\[]\ResourceExample\bin\Debug>resourceexample fr-FR 2004-01-16 09:53:44,381 [2272] INFO [HcaLogger] [] <> - Logger initialized. L'opration a russi. [1000] The preferred of method of accessing resources is to use System.Reflection.MethodBase.GetCurrentMethod().Name as opposed to hard coding the resource name in the constructor calls. If the situation arises where different key names need to be accessed by the same method or different methods need to access the same resource, the string name may be substituted. ... /// /// Used to indicate some message. /// Message: "This is a test message [{0}]." /// /// The name of the item being tested. public static MyAppResourceMessage MyMessage(string itemName) { return new MyAppResourceMessage(MethodBase.GetCurrentMethod().Name, itemName); } /// /// Used to indicate some message. /// Message: "This is a test message [{0}]." /// /// The name of the item being tested. public static MyAppResourceMessage MyOtherMessage(string itemName) { return new MyAppResourceMessage("MyMessage", itemName); } ... Describing the .NET Framework's code and resource compilation mechanisms is beyond the scope of this SDK. However, in case the reader desires to execute this example code, note that the author compiled the above example by executing the following command lines from his ResourceExample\bin\Debug directory: Figure 3:

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Resource.ResourceConfig
member.summary: Configuration class for initializing a .

remarks.para: One or more objects instantiated using this class may be used to initialize a . The property determines the context name which must be specified in subsequent calls to methods.

When multiple resources share the same name and context specified in the call to across ResourceConfigs, their list order in configuration determines precedence. This enables the override capability of the .

All strings are required, that is, in , , or will cause to throw an exception. Duplicate entries are valid and will be given the search priority of the first (highest priority) appearance. Checking for the existence of the AssemblyName's (and BaseName's inside) is left for the when it attempts to consume the ResourceConfig's information.

example.para:
The following example illustrates a sample configuration file describing two objects in a shared context.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <cf:hcaConfigFactory xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://hcaschema.hca.corpad.net/Common/Configuration/2.0/ConfigFactory.xsd ConfigFactory.xsd" xmlns:cf="http://hcaschema.hca.corpad.net/Common/Configuration/2.0/ConfigFactory.xsd"> <config type="Hca.Common.Resource.ResourceConfig" readOnly="true"> <property name="ContextName" value="test1" /> <property name="AssemblyName" value="TestResources" /> <property name="BaseName" value="test1" /> </config> <config type="Hca.Common.Resource.ResourceConfig" readOnly="true"> <property name="ContextName" value="test1" /> <property name="AssemblyName" value="TestResources" /> <property name="BaseName" value="test2" /> </config> </cf:hcaConfigFactory>

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Resource.ResourceHelper
member.summary: A class that wraps one or more .Net (s) with contextual grouping and cascading aggregation functionality.

remarks.para: A .Net handles culture-sensitive access to a set of .resources files, either on the file system, or compiled into a set of assemblies. The wraps this functionality with some additional useful features...

First, multiple ResourceManagers may be searched in a single call, enabling better organization of those files without complicating the code used to access them. There is a concept of priority among the various ResourceManagers, avoiding name collision and allowing overridable resource population (e.g., local customization of a library's default message texts).

Additionally, ResourceManagers may be arbitrarily organized into named groups, called contexts to enable searching within a designated subset. This allows inadvertant naming collisions to be avoided as seperate subsystems search only the appropriate ResourceManagers for their own resources. Once again, priority among contexts allows for search across all contexts with defined handling for name collisions.

Last but not least, the replaceable parameter capabilities of the .Net method have been wrapped in for easy access directly through the . See the .Net documentation and the overloads of the GetString() methods that include the formatArgs and parameters.
Note that at present, some of the .Net functionality has not been included in the . The methods are absent, and the ability to use .resources files directly from the filesystem has not been provided.

example.para:
This first example illustrates basic retrieval of a resource string.
string test = HcaResourceManager.Instance.GetString("context1", "resource1", new object[] {});

Assuming the en-US culture-specific string resource named "resource1" in the context named "context1" is defined as "First value: {0} / Second value: {1} / Third value: {2:C}", this code will populate test with the following string:
First value: foo / Second value: bar / Third value: $678.90
For an example of instantiating a , please see the class.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Service.AroundInterceptor
member.summary: An that allows work to be performed before and after invocation.
member.remarks: This interceptor will call method, call on the invocation, determine if the proceed failed, and then call with failure notice. Implementors of this class just need to implement the abstract Pre- and Post- Proceed methods.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.IInterceptor
member.summary: Interface that defines the interceptor concept. A proxy will call back on this interceptor when it is invoked by a client.

remarks.para: The interceptor receives the proxy invocation and has the opportunity to perform work if desired and then allow method invocation to proceed. Any work performed before or after method invocation is synchronous so if the interceptors are chained together the collective time might be unacceptable. If you need to perform a long running task, then you might want to consider performing the work asynchronously.
Note that, to guarantee proper handling for multi-threaded services, implementations of this interface must ensure thread safety.

member.summary: Receives a proxy invocation and performs any desired work.
member.param: The describing the call being intercepted.
member.returns: The result of invocation - usually (but not necessarily) obtained by calling ..

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Service.ImpersonationInterceptor
member.summary: Interceptor that provides impersonation around the invocation by entering a Windows 32 Identity Context, , for the credential provided. This interceptor provides support for the Trusted Subsystem security model.
member.remarks:
Usually application's security model is either impersonation/delegation or trusted subsystem.
Impersonation/Delegation - The orginal caller's Windows identity is used to access a resource.
Trsuted Subsytem - The caller is authorized to perform an action and the action is performed with the identity of a trusted user which is typically a service account.
If a credential is not provided no context is entered.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Service.LoggingInterceptor
member.summary: Logs DEBUG 'START' and 'FINISH' markers around the invocation chain including the passed in arguments.
member.remarks:
This interceptor should normally be the first interceptor on the stack. An example output from this interceptor is the following:
2006-02-07 08:42:19,856 [DEBUG] CORPPDCDT3837 (3104) LoggingInterceptor [(null)] - START: Service method [PaymentService] invocation with arguments [] 2006-02-07 08:42:19,856 [INFO] CORPPDCDT3837 (3104) ImpersonationInterceptor [(null)] - Impersonating service method call with credential [zzy1234@HCA] 2006-02-07 08:42:19,950 [DEBUG] CORPPDCDT3837 (3104) WindowsSecurity [(null)] - Entering Win32 identity context: setting unmanaged thread identity to [HCA\zzy1234] from [HCA\cdt3837]. 2006-02-07 08:42:19,950 [DEBUG] CORPPDCDT3837 (3104) DisposalHelper [(null)] - Constructed helper for object named [Win32IdentityContext: [HCA\zzy1234]]. 2006-02-07 08:42:19,965 [DEBUG] CORPPDCDT3837 (3104) DisposalHelper [(null)] - MarkDisposed() requested on object named [Win32IdentityContext: [HCA\zzy1234]] by thread [3104]. 2006-02-07 08:42:19,981 [DEBUG] CORPPDCDT3837 (3104) DisposalHelper [(null)] - Thread [3104] has primary request to MarkDisposed() on object named [Win32IdentityContext: [HCA\zzy1234]]: marking helper disposed. 2006-02-07 08:42:19,981 [DEBUG] CORPPDCDT3837 (3104) DisposalHelper [(null)] - MarkDisposed() on object named [Win32IdentityContext: [HCA\zzy1234]] blocking thread [3104] for holds .... 2006-02-07 08:42:19,981 [DEBUG] CORPPDCDT3837 (3104) DisposalHelper [(null)] - MarkDisposed() on object named [Win32IdentityContext: [HCA\zzy1234]] returning on thread [3104]. 2006-02-07 08:42:19,981 [DEBUG] CORPPDCDT3837 (3104) WindowsSecurity [(null)] - Exiting Win32 identity context: resetting unmanaged thread identity back to [HCA\cdt3837]. 2006-02-07 08:42:19,981 [DEBUG] CORPPDCDT3837 (3104) LoggingInterceptor [(null)] - FINISHED: Service method [PaymentService] invocation

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Service.ServiceConfig
member.summary: Defines the instantiation mechanisim and proxy interceptors for a named service object.

remarks.para: Instance of this class are used by . creates a service object by invoking the factory method or constructor described by a object and passing the defined parameters. This allows client code to be compiled without any hard-coded knowledge of how service implementations will be instantiated.

Users can also specify interceptors to be attached to the proxy object. By default, the interceptors returned by will be attached. (Specify the impersonation account using .) This default stack may be extended by specifying , and/or overridden by setting to .

Note that nothing in the configuration indicates what interfaces will be implemented by the service object. It is the responsibility of the caller to ensure that the call to specifies the configuration context of the intended .

supports two styles of service instantiation: (1) invocation of an object constructor, or (2) invocation of a static factory method. The following tables describe how to use the properties for each of these approaches.

item.description: The type whose constructor will be invoked. If multiple overloads exist, will select one using .
The arguments (if any) to pass to the constructor.
Must be .
Must be .
The type containing the static factory method that will be invoked.
Must be .
The name of the static factory method. If multiple overloads exist, will select one using .
The arguments (if any) to pass to the static factory method.

member.example:
Following is sample XML defining two instances of .
<config type="Hca.Common.Service.ServiceConfig" context="Hca.Product.Service.IType:Real"> <property name="ServiceType" value="Hca.Product.Service.Type"/> <property name="ServiceCreationMethod" value="FactoryMethod"/> <property name="ServiceCreationMethodArgs"> <object type="ArgType">argValue</object> </property> <property name="InterceptorStackContext" value="myStack"/> <property name="NetworkCredential"> <property name="Domain" value="HCA" /> <property name="UserName" value="Account" /> <property name="Password" value="*****" /> </property> </config> <config type="Hca.Common.Service.ServiceConfig" context="Hca.Product.Service.IType:Stub"> <property name="ServiceType" value="Hca.Product.Service.Stub"/> <property name="ServiceTypeArgs"> <object type="ArgType">argValue</object> </property> <property name="UseDefaultInterceptorStack" value="false"/> </config>

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Service.ServiceHelper
member.summary: Helper class for services.

remarks.p: A service is an interface that defines specific behavior that may be used by other parts of the system or systems. It layers the system making it more manageable.

The service helper provides support for creating and proxying services. A proxy is a class that is emitted to support the service's interfaces. This emitted class is returned to the user to interact with. Upon method invocation of this class the passed in interceptor will be called.

When a consumer invokes the interface-backed proxy, the proxy will call a chained list of interceptors defined in the . Each will have an opportunity to perform some work and then choose to proceed or not to proceed. If the interceptor proceeds then the next interceptor has an opportunity to perform some work. This continues until an interceptor has chosen to stop the invocation call or the last interceptor is reached. The last interceptor proceed call will invoke the appropriate service method.

Interceptors allow behavior to be aspected to services in a clean manner without adding code to the actual service implementation. By default, is used which provides impersonation, timing, and logging behaviors. You can provide your own interceptor stack if the default does not meet your need.

The helper is designed to provide a service proxy that allows common functionality to be reused across services. Typical usage for most applications is instantiate your service class and pass it to the method. Component writers that want proxy services for their components may use this helper as well. They would provide a component factory class which would in turn use this helper class.
Note that all the interfaces the service class implements will be proxied. Therefore, it is best practice that the service class only implement service interfaces.

members.member:
Ensures that loading of HCA assemblies is reported correctly by .Net's and .
There is a bug in .Net 1.1 where an assembly from the GAC may not ever be reported as loaded in a given application domain if another application domain in the same process has already loaded it. This appears to be a side-effect of .Net's assembly loading optimization which loads the JIT-compiled code of shared assemblies into a process-wide "shared domain".
This class enables a work-around by tracing the static (i.e., compile-time) references of the assemblies that are reported loaded. Unfortunately, this does involve a performance hit as assemblies that may not yet (or ever) be dynamically referenced will be loaded simply by virtue of a static reference.
To minimize this performance hit, this class's dependency loading has been limited to assemblies whose name begins with "HCA". This is sufficient to solve the HCA-typical problem occasioned by this bug - failure of to load configuration files specified by . If a referenced assembly cannot be loaded, the exception will be logged processing will continue.
\

member.summary: Compares two objects and returns a value indicating whether one is less than, equal to or greater than the other.

list.para: Less than zero if is less than .
Greater than zero if is greater than .

member.remarks: This method works by calling through to the inner comparers passed to the constructor. They are invoked one at a time, in order, until a non-zero value is returned or all the comparers are exhausted.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Utility.DisposalHelper
member.summary: A helper class for implementing over multi-threaded classes.
member.remarks:
Functional Requirements abstracts the intricacies of coordinating disposal of multi-threaded implementations. (See MsNetIDisp.)
Tenets
Classes that allocate unmanaged resources must implement .
Classes that wrap usage of other objects should implement .
Classes that implement should ensure instance thread-safety to guarantee the integrity of their resource allocations.
Multi-threaded classes should use .
Design .NET defines the interface for classes that must interact with unmanaged resources. (See MsNetIDisp.) In brief, the interface specifies that the client of a disposable object should call as soon as the object is no long needed. This signals the object to release its resources. Consistent with this, the interface additionally stipulates that once has been called, all methods (other than ) must throw .
Complexities arise when the implementing class must ensure safety in multi-threading scenarios. Two new considerations immediately come into play:
must block while any already-executing methods finish executing.
Once starts blocking, new calls to other methods should throw .
This class is designed to assist developers who are facing these issues. It allows a client to acquire and release individual 'holds' (similar to a Monitor lock) for operations that must complete before returns. It abstracts setting the 'disposed' flag with a method () that immediately sets an internal flag, and then blocks for any holds. It also provides properties for testing for existing holds, and for testing the disposed state.
Microsoft's .NET documentation illustrates a baseline implementation of . (See MsNetIDisp.) Their example is a single class which wraps both managed and unmanaged scarce resources and implements to handle release of those resources. However, it does not address actual usage of those resources nor does it attempt to ensure thread safety. Microsoft's example is reproduced below (sans comments).
Usage Multi-threaded class that implements (see MsNetIDisp) should have a private field of type . When the containing class is constructed, the helper must be instantiated with a string that will describe the object if the helper must throw an .
Then, each code block (method or segment thereof) that could conflict with resource disposal must be wrapped in a disposal hold. The hold is obtained through a call to the helper's method, and released by a call to . When the object's method is called, it must in turn call the helper's . From then on, subsequent calls to throw the appropriate . However, all existing hold blocks (and any additional hold requests nested in those blocks) will be allowed to execute, and is not returned until all holds have been released. As a convenience, also returns an indicator of whether it actually changed state or had been called previously. In the latter case, cleanup has been handled elsewhere and should not be executed by the calling thread.)
This is a fairly simple usage pattern that is illustrated in the Examples section.

by a corresponding call to this 's , or

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Utility.ElapseTime
member.summary: Used to mark one to many response times. The times are given in milliseconds.
member.remarks:
Functional Requirements
Provide consistent, convenient method for measuring elapsed time.
Support single measurements as well as multiple measurements.
Report total elapsed time, current elapsed time, and average elapsed time.
Track time for a single machine.
Tenets should not use to track time across multiple machines.
Design This class provides a convenient method for time measurement. There are many uses for this class. Some obvious examples are code profiling, instrumentation for runtime performance, and time measurement in general for time sensitive operations.
In addition to providing a single time measurement, can provide the total elapsed time and the average elapsed time over a series of samples. In addition, you can get the series of data points used to determine elapsed time.
Usage This class is used to mark one to many response times. This class can also be used to mark just a begin/end time or used to mark a begin and a moving end times. A key is used to distinguish between other entries.

hcaExample.code:
ElapseTime.MarkTime(key, true); //ensures a new response time ...some work ElapseTime.MarkTime(key); //increment response time ...more work ElapseTime.MarkTime(key); //increment response time
log.Info(ElapseTime.GetResponseTime(key).TotalElapseTime);

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Utility.HashCodeGenerator
member.summary: This class provides a means to generate a hashcode for an object that is based on all fields of a class. This is useful if the client of this class overrides to provide value semantics equality and hence needs to provide the hashcode implementation that considers this.
member.remarks:
Functional Requirements class must derive a value-based hash code from any given object.
Tenets This class must support implementations that conform to three of the four rules laid out by .NET:
If two objects are equal (i.e., their methods return when the other object is passed in as a parameter), they must have the same hash code.
The value returned by cannot change, even if member variables change their value. This rule is only applicable for immutable value types. does not support this rule.
The function must not have circular references or throw exceptions. does throw one exception. See the Design section below for details.
Objects that override must override .
Of these rules, two is problematic and in fact all ValueTypes within the .NET framework break. The problem is that for rule two to be enforced, the class must either be immutable or the hashcode must be based on a constant value that is unique for an instance (i.e. like the heap address of the object). Unfortunately, this is not very useful in many cases and more importantly breaks rule one if equals is defined in terms of value based comparison. The real reason for rule two was to deal with collections that used the hashcode of a value as its key into the collection. However, it is possible to deal with this situation by designing wrappers to the object to store such that the immutable nature can be maintained by the wrapper or using an immutable key to the object value instead of the hashcode of the object. This puts additional burden in using hash based collections but this is better than the alternative of always returning a new type when an object has a mutable operation performed. Therefore, clients of this class should consider the usage of this class for generation of hashcodes and handle the resultant consequences.
Design This class has a method, , which derives a value-based hash code from any given object. It iterates through parent and child objects including arrays and collections. In general, every value in the object will be factored into the returned hash code. However, there are two exceptions to this rule:
If an object in the graph has the applied, then the object will be ignored for hash code purposes.
may call on any object in the graph that does not implement . If an object implements in terms of without implementing , an infinite loop can result. detects this loop and throws a .
This class uses the FNV1a algorithm for computing hash values. You can find more details on the algorithm at .
This class does handle aggregates (arrays and collection) and hence if you have an object that has object references or sequences, it will recurse into those objects and get the hashcode of their elements until only leaf nodes are reached.
Cycles are detected in self referencing or cyclical relationships (such as common with bi-directional reln) and are not recursed (i.e, we satisfy rule three above).
Parent classes are navigated until either at the top base class or a class is reached that is in the excluded packages list. If is passed for the exclude list, this class automatically adds the and namespace since it is not typical that equality should be based on field values in a .NET base class. However, this is not to say that if the start class is a type that its values would not be evaluated, only that its parents type would not be navigated.
Since this class uses reflection, if byte code security is placed on a class and this class can't gain access to a member, that member is ignored (i.e., no exceptions are thrown to once again satisfy rule 3). Hence care should be taken when using this class in these cases especially if secured members are necessary to calculate a hashcode.
Usage This can be used to derive a value-base hash code from an object. Value-based means that each member in the object's graph is taken into account in deriving the hash code. This class also has a method that will calculate a hash code using FNV1-a given a binary data array. also has a method that can also be used in methods that need a instance.
Configuration class should have one or more limiting namespaces specified, which indicate the top most parent class(es) to compare for an object. If no limiting namespace is specified then class compares the object's parent, then the parent's parent, etc. By default, the namespace is excluded form traversal.
This limiting namespace should be as specific as is needed to ensure a correct comparison. A higher-level namespace will encompass all of its child namespaces as well. Any collection of namespaces to exclude is in addition to the default namespace.
Best Practices Use the ObjectBase.GetHashCode method instead of the class when implementing classes that inherit from . can be used outside of where needed.

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.HashCodeGenerator.CalculateHashCode(System.Object)

overloads.summary: This method provides calculation of a hashcode by using all fields and properties of the passed class.

remarks.p: Any member which is not accessible is not considered into the comparison. members are also not included since their values would always be the same for all instances of a class and hence including them adds unnecessary processing.

This hash function does not ensure unique values but attempts to provide reasonable distribution of the hash values. If does not contribute to the hash value since its value is the same and hence the current hash at the point of evaluation is returned when is encountered. If an exception occurs a hashcode of zero is returned.

summary.p: This overload will exclude navigation into any Parent type that is within the and namespace. If you need to navigate into a parent of type , use the method that takes an explicit namespace list and provide an empty array and (NOT ).

member.param: The object to compute a hashcode on
member.returns: int, hashcode value or zero if input or exception

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.HashCodeGenerator.CalculateHashCode(System.Object,System.String[])
member.summary: This overload will only navigate into parent types that are not within the excluded namespace list.
member.remarks: If is passed for the argument, is included by default. If an empty array is passed, all namespaces are included. Otherwise, the namespaces listed are excluded as specified.
member.param: The object to compute a hashcode on
