member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.HashCodeGenerator.Fnv1aHashFunction(System.UInt32,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Generalized implementation of the FNV1a Hash Algorithm as defined by Landon Curt Null .

remarks.p: When using this function, pass zero when you hash the first value. This will seed the has with a suitable prime to help ensure good random distribution. When hashing objects or structs, you must break down every item to a primitive type so that it can be converted to a representative byte array.
The unsigned int that is returned should be cast to an int in the final return for use with hashing that requires an int.

member.param: Zero, for first data value, else current hash.
member.returns: A reasonably random hash value of the given data.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Utility.PropertyUtility
member.summary: Utility class for using reflection to facilitate generic property operations on objects.
member.remarks:
Functional Requirements provides convenient methods for developers to work with object properties. It provides the ability to get, set, and determine a property's read and write capabilities. It allows a set of properties to be copied from a source object to a target object. For the getter and setter methods, the property names may be specified in a nested dot notation format that includes index properties. The setter method also provides coercion capabilities.
Tenets uses reflection to manipulate the properties. It is important to take into account its performance impact if used in time sensitive tasks.
Design This is a powerful utility allowing the user to easily manipulate properties on an object as well as copy properties between objects. The utility uses reflection to discover an object's properties and traverse the property name. Coercion is handled by type converters registered to types. This class allows exceptions to bubble up through its public methods without using the exception handler to properly log and wrap exceptions. This is because the namespace is further up the namespace hierarchy than and thus cannot use it.
Usage This utility is used to get or set a property, copy properties from one object to another, and check a property to see if you can read or write to it. For the getter and setter methods, you can pass in a property name that indicates a chain of properties where the last property is the one you want to get or set. Within this chain you can also name index properties.
When declaring an indexed property in getting or setting a property, Item should be used to indicate the indexed property on the object.
All property names provided to set or get properties may be in the form of simple or complex property name. Simple property names are just one property. Complex property names may indicate a list of properties that need to be traversed. For instance, the propertyName can be a in a dot notation where each token maps to a property. This allows you to specify nested properties. This is useful when you want to set or get a property without having to call multiple getters. The tokens can be expressed in the following format:
simple - name
complex - name.name.name
indexed - name[index]
indexed - name[index, index]
combined - name.name[index].name
By default, the binding flags used to determine the set of properties for an object are based on its instance, public, and declared properties in the passed object. For all methods, you can pass in your own set of binding flags to override the default. The main purpose is to copy properties at the top level not performing some deep copy or clone. See for performing a deep clone. There is an overloaded property that allows the bindings to be explicitly declared. This means you can control how properties are discovered for manipulation. See .
For the setter and copy methods, you can define how the methods should handle nulls. For instance, should nulls from a source object property be copied to the target? Or, should only null properties on the target be valued? In addition, for setter properties you can indicate if you want coercion to take place. This is used when the property value passed in is a string and you want it to be coerced to the appropriate type for the target property.

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.PropertyUtility.CopyProperties(System.Object,System.Object)

overloads.summary: Copy all properties from one object to another. The properties are not cloned but just referenced assigned.

remarks.para: The property names are considered simple only. Indexed properties are not copied. Only properties with a getter to read and setter to write are copied.

Overloads that define formal parameters of target type and source type allow a caller to specify the base type to use when searching for properties. If , the passed object's type is used. Otherwise the passed type is used to get properties. The is needed when a class has a chain of one or more concrete parent classes and a virtual method uses this method to copy properties at the current classes level and calls its parent to do the same. In this case if the target and source types are used, the parents call will use that type instead of its type which means that the parent properties will not be copied, only the most derived class' properties.

member.summary: This overload uses the target and source types and default and .

member.returns: the number of properties copied

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.ResponseTime.Clone
member.summary: At this level just return the value created by object's (shallow copy semantics). Note that the owner object is not cloned since it could lead to recursion looping. This is ok in the case where the clone is used as a snapshot of the existing object for printing or viewing. However, if this operation is being used to create a new instance, the owner should be reset with the new parent created outside this operation so the correct reference is valued.
member.remarks: If a shallow copy isn't appropriate for an object, then this method can be overridden using the interface.
member.returns: The cloned object

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.ResponseTime.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Method to test equality of one object to another. Equality tests should include all attributes that contribute to what distinguishes one instance of an object to another.
member.remarks: This method uses a compare utility that checks all fields for equality including fields in any parent class as long as that parent class is a user defined class and not a .Net Framework class (value semantics equality). Further, any composite types are drilled into and checked for equality. Derived classes SHOULD NOT override this method unless they have special value semantics that a straight comparison would not handle. The object to compare against
member.returns: if this object and the passed object have the same value

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Utility.SerializationUtility
member.summary: Provides static methods for common serialization and deserialization tasks.
member.remarks:
Functional Requirements Provides convenient methods for developers to implement compatible changes to pre-existing serializable classes. The class is intended to provide methods for tasks that recur commonly in serialization and deserialization scenarios.
Tenets Provides convenient methods for developers who must implement compatible changes to pre-existing serializable classes.
Design Compatible changes to a class often include the addition of methods or fields. This is considered compatible because pre-existing client code can ignore the new members as long as the existing members and their semantics have not changed. This backward compatibility becomes less simple, however, in the context of a serializable class that must reconstruct serialized instances of older versions of the class. .NET's deserialization operations (, etc.) [MsNetSerialize] assume that the lack of a requested member is an error state, and throw an exception. However, if the member has been added to class since the object was serialized, the member's absence from the serialized instance is not an error. Therefore, the exception must be caught and the member assigned a default or placeholder value. provides shortcuts for the developer who is implementing this workaround.
At present, the missing-value-aware wrappers for SerializationInfo.GetValue and its variants are the only methods provided.
Usage This utility adds a new serializable member to a class, to handle the case where the revised class must deserialize an older instance in which the new member did not exist. When the new member is requested from the old serialized instance, can catch the exception thrown by [MsNetSerialize] and provide an appropriate value for the missing member.
For each of SerializationInfo's retrieval methods (GetValue and its type-sensitive variants), provides a set of overloaded wrapper methods. Three styles of overload are provided. One simply passes the call directly to the SerializationInfo. The other two overloads also pass the call through to , but they can suppress the member not found exception one by returning the type's default value, and the other by returning a value supplied by the caller.
Best Practices It is suggested that all deserialization operations use the , rather than directly calling the methods. Although this measure may be technically unnecessary in the initial incarnation of a class' serialization implementation (most likely using the wrapper methods' first overload), it is recommended for two reasons:
The reference to should remind future developers to handle new serialized members intelligently.
It provides stylistic consistency across code areas.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Utility.StandardRegularExpression
member.summary: An essentially class that provides regular expressions for general use.
member.remarks: Unless otherwise specified, will always return for a valid check. Also note that no modification of the string is made before the check. Hence, if you have leading or trailing whitespace, it will fail the expression if whitespace is not allowed as valid characters.

member.summary: Hide Constructor

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.StandardRegularExpression.IsValidThreeFourId(System.String)
member.summary: Returns if the 3-4 is in a valid format
member.remarks: If is passed, is always returned. A 3-4 id is made of three letters followed by 4 digits where the last 4 digits can't be all zeros and the first three letters don't include offensive words.
member.returns: if valid

member.summary: Returns the three part of the 34 id if valid. Otherwise String.Empty is returned.

member.returns: the three part of the id or empty

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.StandardRegularExpression.IsFakeSsn(System.String)
member.summary: Return if the string passed in is a fake ssn.
member.remarks: A fake ssn is one that starts with three leading zeros. If is passed, this will always return .
member.returns: if fake

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.StandardRegularExpression.IsValidSsn(System.String)
member.summary: Return if the string is a valid ssn.
member.remarks:
If is passed, is always returned. Per Gov spec: http://www.socialsecurity.gov/employer/ssnweb.htm The following rule are used to determine an invalid ssn.
Starts with an eight
Starts with a nine
Starts with three zeros
Starts with three sixes
All ones
All threes
Is a sequential number
Not all digits
Each grouping may have zero or more space, tab or dash characters between them and still match. For example:
124 67 7890 124-67-7890 124 67 7890
would all match.
member.returns: if valid format ssn

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.StandardRegularExpression.GetAreaPartOfSsn(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the Area part (first three numbers)of a ssn if valid. Otherwise String.Empty is returned.
member.remarks: If is passed, an String.Empty is always returned.
member.returns: The Area part of the ssn or empty

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.StandardRegularExpression.GetGroupPartOfSsn(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the group part (middle two numbers) if valid. Otherwise String.Empty is returned.
member.remarks: If is passed, an String.Empty is always returned.
member.returns: The group part of ssn

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.StandardRegularExpression.GetSequencePartOfSsn(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the sequence part (last four numbers) of an SSN if valid. Otherwise String.Empty is returned.
member.remarks: If is passed, an String.Empty is always returned.
member.returns: The sequence part of ssn

member.summary: Returns the sequence part (last four numbers) of a Fake SSN. Otherwise String.Empty is returned.
member.remarks: If is passed, an String.Empty is always returned.
member.returns: The sequence part of ssn

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.StandardRegularExpression.IsValidNorthAmericanPhoneNumber(System.String)
member.summary: Returns if a valid phone number.
member.remarks:
North American (USA, Canada, Caribbean Islands, and US territories) current format is of the form: NXX NXX XXXX [Extension] (where N is 2-9 and X is 0-9) Within the area code certain combinations are reserved or not usable for regular use this includes N11, N9X, 37X, and 96X. This is subject to change especially for the N9X, 37X, and 96X restrictions. New format would be: NXX(X) (X)NXX XXXX (where (X) is the added digit. Note N restriction would evidentially be removed.) Note however, this code does not check new format since it is not in use yet. North American Standards referenced can be found at: NANPA
Groups must be separated by a space(s), a hyphen, or a period between them. Extensions may be delimited by 'extension', 'extn', 'ext', 'ex', 'xtn', 'e', 'x', '-', '.', ',', with an optional period or colon. Extensions are limited to 5 digits. In researching phone number data in Active Directory it was discovered that the greatest variation of formats are with extensions. Often incorrect extensions are entered such as 'e...' to indicate no entry. In these cases, the extension is ignored.

member.summary: Return the Area Code of the phone number or empty string if not valued.
member.remarks: If is passed, String.Empty is always returned. Refer to for details on formatting rules.
member.param: The number to get the area code from
member.returns: the Area Code or String.Empty if not valued.

member.param: The number to get the prefix from
member.returns: the Prefix or String.Empty.

member.param: The number to get the extension from
member.returns: the Extension value or String.Empty.

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.StandardRegularExpression.IsValidInternationalPhoneNumber(System.String)
member.summary: Return if number can be parsed as an international number.
member.remarks:
International numbers must be parsed based on the number of distinguishable groups in the value passed. All numbers must include the Country Code[CC] and the Subscriber number[SN]. A subscriber number can further be broken into three parts: National Designation Code (NDC) ( aka area code) Prefix (usually an exchange office or node point) (P) Local Number (LN) Extension (always follows the LN and designated by an extension delimiter. The following groupings are recognized [CC][SN] [CC][NDC][LN] [CC][NDC][P][LN] The country code may have a + which is standard notation for international numbers. The area code (NDC) can have surrounding parentheses but both must be specified or the number is considered invalid. Groups must be separated by a space(s), a hyphen, or a period between them. Extensions digits are limited to 5.
The following groupings are recognized [CC][SN] [CC][NDC][LN] [CC][NDC][P][LN]
The country code may have a + which is standard notation for international numbers. The area code (NDC) can have surrounding parentheses but both must be specified or the number is considered invalid.
Extensions may be delimited by 'extension', 'extn', 'ext', 'ex', 'xtn', 'e', 'x', '-', '.', ',', with an optional period or colon. Extensions are limited to 5 digits. In researching phone number data in Active Directory it was discovered that the greatest variation of formats are with extensions. Often incorrect extensions are entered such as 'e...' to indicate no entry. In these cases, the extension is ignored.
member.example:
The Following represent valid international numbers:
Form 1: +672 134578 Form 2: +32 105-56457 Form 3: +1 (205) 768-3456 With Extension: +672 134578 ext. 123 +32 105-56457 x 345 +1 (205) 768-3456 ex: 78
member.returns: if valid international number

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.StandardRegularExpression.GetCountryCodeOfInternationalPhoneNumber(System.String)
member.summary: Return the country code of an international phone number
member.returns: The country code or String.Empty if invalid international number

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.StandardRegularExpression.GetAreaCodeOfInternationalPhoneNumber(System.String)
member.summary: Return the area code of an international phone number
member.remarks: This really gets the National destination code (NDC)of the subscriber number part of the phone number. Many countries call this the area code but it can also represent the city code or national prefix. Since an international number does not have to have an area code, this will return an String.Empty when not valued.
member.returns: The area code or String.Empty if invalid international number or area code not specified

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.StandardRegularExpression.GetPrefixOfInternationalPhoneNumber(System.String)
member.summary: Return the prefix of an international phone number
member.remarks: The prefix will only be returned if the number is composed such that it can be Recognized within the passed phone number. Refer to for patterns that are Recognized. It is expected that this will return the String.Empty often since many countries do not distinguish prefixes from the local number.
member.returns: The prefix or String.Empty if invalid international number or prefix not specified

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.StandardRegularExpression.GetLocalNumberOfInternationalPhoneNumber(System.String)
member.summary: Return the Local Number of the phone number.
member.remarks: If is passed, String.Empty is always returned. Refer to for details on formatting rules.
member.param: The number to get the local number from
member.returns: the Local Number or String.Empty if passed or invalid phone number.

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.StandardRegularExpression.GetExtensionOfInternationalPhoneNumber(System.String)
member.summary: Return the Extension of the phone number.
member.remarks: If is passed, String.Empty is always returned. Refer to for details on formatting rules.
member.param: The number to get the extension from
member.returns: the Extension value or String.Empty if phone number , invalid or extension not specified.

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.StandardRegularExpression.StripOffExtensionOfInternationalPhoneNumber(System.String)
member.summary: Return the phone number without the extension.
member.remarks: If is passed, String.Empty is always returned. Refer to for details on formatting rules.
member.param: The number to get the extension from
member.returns: the phone number value without the extension or String.Empty.

member.summary: This utility method will return the passed argument as a trimmed string if it has a value (i.e. not and not an empty string). Otherwise, it returns .
member.returns: Either a trimmed string with Length > 0, or .

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Utility.SystemUtility
member.summary: This class provides methods that are common to all systems and don't fall into any existing category.
member.remarks:
Functional Requirements class must contain methods that are complementary to .NET system level methods. These are methods that you need but the core API did not provide this functionality.
Tenets For , any object that is copied must be serializable. should be used to check most string input parameters so users do not have to worry about trimming their input. It also provides a consistent way to check to see if the string was provided. We recommend that rather than empty strings are passed back. This ensures that the return string is trimmed and not empty.
Design This class provides helper methods that complement .NET's namespace. It has one method that performs a deep copy and one that cleans a string so that any null value is converted to any empty string.
The deep copy method serializes that object and deserializes it into a new object.
Usage This class provides methods that are common to all systems and don't fall into any particular category.

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.SystemUtility.#ctor
member.summary: Default Constructor

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.SystemUtility.DeepCopy(System.Object)
member.summary: Makes a replica of the passed object that replicates all members of the object recursively.
member.remarks:
This replica should be semantically meaningful (i.e., the new instance should be in a valid state given it's a new object.) This method Serializes the object and Deserializes it into a new object. Therefore, this method will only work on an object the is marked with the [Serializable] attribute.
The Serialization functionality can be overridden by an object using the interface.
member.returns: a complete copy of the object
member.exception: Will be thrown if the object is not marked serializable.

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.SystemUtility.NullOrTrimString(System.String)
member.summary: This utility method will return the passed argument as a trimmed string if it has a value (i.e. not and not an empty string). Otherwise, it returns .

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.SystemUtility.GetCurrentDomainAssemblies
member.summary: Gathers all the domain assemblies and returns an array of strings displaying the assembly full name and where it is located (GAC or local).
member.remarks:
This output might be used on a diagnostic page showing all assemblies, their version, and where they are loading from. By default, the logger outputs this information as well when it is first called.
You might also have a console application that talks to the app and calls this method to output its assemblies.
Typical output would look like the following:
Assembly 'log4net, Version=1.2.0.30714, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b32731d11ce58905' from 'GAC' Assembly 'mscorlib, Version=1.0.5000.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089' from 'c:\winnt\microsoft.net\framework\v1.1.4322\mscorlib.dll'
member.returns: An array of strings

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.SystemUtility.GetFields(System.Type,System.Object,System.Type,System.Object)

overloads.summary: This method returns for fields in a passed instance.
overloads.remarks:
Since the method in does not recurse the parent inheritance chain for non-public fields (even when the indicate to do so), this method provides that capability and hence is a replacement for the method. However, if your need is to only include public fields, use the for this purpose.
If the instance passed is , the routine returns immediately and does not modify the array list passed If the type to check is , the instance type is used as the start type for getting fields. This method does not recurse into the System.Object class.

member.summary: This overload will return all public and non-public fields for a class inclusive of fields in parent classes which have the given attribute and value.
member.remarks: If the attribute Type is , no attributes are used to filter the resulting fields returned and is as if you called . If the attribute Value is checked, it is check against the value passed even if .
member.param: The Type to start the check from.
The object instance to retrieve fields from
The of the attribute to filter the return list of fields
A value that the field's value is checked against
member.returns: An array of zero or more objects

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.SystemUtility.GetFields(System.Object,System.Type,System.Object)
member.summary: This overload will return all public and non-public fields for a class inclusive of fields in parent classes which have the given attribute and value using the instance's type as the type to start getting fields.
member.remarks: If the attribute Type is , no attributes are used to filter the resulting fields returned and is as if you called . If the attribute Value is checked, it is check against the value passed even if .
member.param: The object instance to retrieve fields from
The of the attribute to filter the return list of fields
A value that the field's value is checked against

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Utility.ValueComparator
member.summary: This class takes two objects and will determine if they are equivalent. Equivalence means that both objects are of the same type and have the same values (where "same values" is defined as if the two items compare equal using the method (if a value object), or by equating each part of a composite object.
member.remarks:
Functional Requirements class must implement a full value comparison of two objects.
Tenets Any two objects that are compared must be of the same type.
Design This class has only one method, , which performs a full value for value comparison of two objects. It iterates through parent and child objects, including arrays and collections. In general, every value in the two objects must be the same for the comparison to be equal. However, there are two exceptions to this rule:
If a class implements , then the equality is determined by this implementation.
If a class has the applied, then any two objects of this class will always be equal. This attribute essentially tells the to ignore the object.
This class does handle aggregates (arrays and collection) and hence if you have an object that has object references or sequences, it will recurse into those objects and compare their elements until only leaf nodes are reached. Cycles are detected in self referencing or cyclical relationships (such as common with bi-directional reln) and are not recursed.
Since this class uses reflection, if byte code security is placed on a class and this class can't gain access to a member, that member is ignored. Hence care should be taken when using this class in these cases especially if secured members are necessary to equate equality. One solution is for that class to implement the interface so that the interface may be used without having to drill into the parts of the class.
Usage This class is used to compare two objects and determine if they are equivalent. Equivalence means that both objects are of the same type and have the same values (where "same values" is defined as if the two items compare equal using the method (if a value object), or by equating each part of a composite object.
Configuration The class should have one or more limiting namespaces specified, which indicate the top most parent class(es) to compare for an object. If no limiting namespace is specified then class compares the object's parent, then the parent's parent, etc. By default, the namespace is excluded from traversal.
This limiting namespace should be as specific as is needed to ensure a correct comparison. A higher-level namespace will encompass all of its child namespaces as well. Any collection of namespaces to exclude is in addition to the default namespace.
Parent classes are navigated until the top most class is reached or a class is reached that is in the excluded packages list. If is passed for the excluded list, the and namespace is excluded by default. If an empty exclude list is passed, no namespaces are excluded. Otherwise, the namespaces listed using a starts with comparison are excluded for navigation.
It is recommended that System be a value in the list since it is not advisable to compare up into the .NET framework classes(Unfortunately, Microsoft did not serialize all members of a their classes while also not marking them such that you could know via reflection that the member was not included and hence there is no way to determine whether to compare or not compare the property.)
This class also takes the interface into account and will use that if the class implements this interface. This will allow a class to define special equivalence semantics as needed. When collections are encountered, the interface is used to iterate through the list of elements. If the is an then comparison is done using contains checking instead of ordered element checking as is done for all other collection types.
Since types are containers, no members present in the base collection type are used for comparison purposes. By default current collection types in .NET and our custom types do not define in fields that contribute to the value for comparison purposes. However, if this is the case you should override since this takes precedence over .
Best Practices Use the class' ObjectBase.Equals method instead of the class when comparing objects that inherit from . class can be used outside of where needed.

member.name: M:Hca.Common.Utility.ValueComparator.IsEqual(System.Object,System.Object)
member.overloads: This method provides equivalence checking for two objects.
member.summary: This method provides equivalence checking for two objects with no namespace exclusions.
member.remarks: Value objects from the .Net framework compare equal if their Equals method returns true. User defined objects compare equal if their parts inclusive of drill-down into members are equal based on member by member equivalence. Any member which is not accessible is not considered into the comparison. If an unexpected exception occurs, a runtime exception is thrown.
member.returns: if the objects compare equal
member.exception: Thrown if unexpected exception occurs

member.remarks: Value objects from the .Net framework compare equal if their Equals method returns true. User defined objects compare equal if their parts inclusive of drill-down into members are equal based on member by member equivalence. Any member which is not accessible is not considered into the comparison. If an unexpected exception occurs, a runtime exception is thrown.
member.param: An array of strings of namespaces that should be excluded for evaluation.
member.returns: if the objects compare equal
member.exception: Thrown if unexpected exception occurs

member.name: T:Hca.Common.Utility.WindowsSecurity
member.summary: Provides static methods abstracting baseline .NET and Win32 security operations.

remarks.para: The methods provided by this class break out into three related areas:
takes standard Windows credentials (domain, username, password) and returns a logged-on Windows identity.
and may be used to query the security information associated with the current thread.
and may be used to temporarily modify the security information associated with the current thread.

It is important to understand the distinction between the concepts of ".NET principal" and "Win32 identity". The term "Win32 identity" is used to refer to the unmanaged (i.e., non-.NET), process-level account token. This token is used to authorize access to Windows resources (such as the file system), as well as SQL Server (when using integrated authentication).

The term ".NET principal" refers to the instance associated with the current thread's managed wrapper (see and ). This identity is usually used to represent the client on whose behalf some server code is executing (e.g., the browser user in ASP.NET).

Note that manipulating the Win32 identity is inherently both costlier and riskier than manipulating the .NET principal. Cost is greater because it requires calls into unmanaged code. Risk is greater because of the low-level resource access that may be available to some Windows accounts.

member.name: T:Hca.Common.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
Objectives This document explains the use of the Common framework classes. is a class library that contains base classes, utility classes, small frameworks, and more. Together it represents a set of patterns and ideas. Some ideas build upon each other in the framework. provides answers to the following:
Logging
Storing and obtaining application configuration information
Defining and obtaining resources
Defining and handling exceptions
Defining and obtaining services
Base class for transfer objects
New data types like nullable value types
Scope This document provides best practices and illustrative examples to show the intent of use of the various parts of the framework. The document is broken into two general areas, deployment of the framework within a project and a series of usage guides that talk about each part of the framework. This document is subject to change as new releases of the framework are released. Please refer to the document history section for details on these releases.
Audience Developers are the prime audience for this document. However, technical testing and code review personnel may find this document useful to understand the appropriate use of the classes.
References The following works are referenced in this SDK:
Table 1: Referenced Works
Label Title Reference
NAnt NAnt build tool
Ant Ant build tool
Design is analogous to .NET's namespace as all of HCA's reusable framework and applications extend from to some degree. packages key concepts like logging, exception handling, configuration creation, object identification, etc. Unlike .NET's namespace, does not throw all its classes into one namespace.
.NET's namespace includes over 130 classes in one namespace.
It partitions them into logical concepts like , , , , , etc. These partitions ensure that the class does not become entangled or blurred with another concept. In addition, circular dependency between namespaces is avoided. This prevents coupling of classes and possible introduction of hard to find bugs as well as making future refactoring difficult. Figure 1 details 's current namespace hierarchy. This diagram illustrates what each namespace is allowed to depend on, not how each namespace does depend on each other. For example, cannot depend on any other namespace and can use any namespace.
Figure 1: Namespace Hierarchy
Build and Deployment
Project Build Process Using NAnt NAnt is a build process ported from Ant. NAnt is used to build and package . This section is intended for people that are developing .
DevPack should be installed first. This ensures that the latest NAnt is installed with proper path settings. There is a build file supplied under the src folder of . Within Visual Studio, right-click the build file and execute the desired target.
Placement of Common DLL and Configuration File and its dependencies should be installed with its install package, DevBlocksCommon - #.#.#.#.msi. The install package places the assemblies in the GAC for compatibility with COM+. The configuration files for and log4net may be placed in the application domain's base directory or specified in the application's configuration file. See and for more details.
The install package will install the following in 's install directory:
Table 2: Package Contents
Location Title Description
bin Release Files
This folder includes the DLL release, its dependencies, and debug symbols. Correlating with the DLL's are XML files that provide intellisense help. An ObjectBuilderTest.config file is also provided as reference on how to write config objects in XML.
doc Documentation Folder
This folder includes the API help file for and log4net. It also includes a release.txt file showing the issues resolved for each release. This usage guide is here as well.
src Source Files
This folder includes the source files released in along with the unit test files that are not included in the release DLL.
Debugging Common 's debug symbols are installed with 's assembly. This file is the same name as the DLL but ends with a PDB extension. You need to add a reference to 's bin directory in your solution's properties under Debug Symbol Files. It is also necessary to add a reference to 's src directory in your solution's properties under Debug Source Files. This allows you to open a source file that is called by the code and place a break point in it. You can then run in debug mode and the IDE will load 's debug symbols and interpret your breakpoint properly.
Usage within ASP.NET Applications In general, 's usage patterns of Web-based applications are no different than any other type of application. For Web applications, one exception is that the default location of the DevBlocks configuration files (logging.config) is the application base directory and not the directory where the main assembly resides (typically the bin directory). This behavior is consistent with the way that the .NET framework handles the web.config file. If is used in an ASPX page, it is necessary to add a @ Assembly directive in the page. For example:
<%@ Assembly Name="HcaDevBlocksCommon, Version=1.3.0.1, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=fd260fd4a2a56402" %>
Where X.X is the current version of Common.
Considerations of use with Existing Projects This section describes possible uses for in an existing project. For instance, a product might be receiving a feature upgrade and the decision is made to incorporate into this product. What areas of should be considered for incorporation?
Must Consider Items or features of that should be incorporated into an existing product or project include:
Refactor application exceptions to extend from . This allows the application to be modified to use .
should handle caught exceptions. This allows the application to benefit from 's rich capabilities of handling both native and HCA specific exceptions and provide consistent logging of these exceptions.
Public methods for services should be wrapped in a try/catch using to handle the exception.
All diagnostic calls should be replaced with . This will abstract out diagnostic information so it and the output sinks can be modified as needed.
All user messages should be placed in resource files and obtained through .
Might Consider Items or features that should be considered for incorporation into an existing product or project include:
If the application is not currently a service-oriented design, then this design approach might be considered. Service-oriented architecture provides coarse grain functionality reuse that is very beneficial. When services are used or any major functionality is incorporated into an interface design, then ServiceFactory should be used to abstract the service's creation.
If the application incorporates a domain model, should be considered as the base object for transfer objects.

member.remarks: This attribute is intended to be used in validation calls. Based on the validation (e.g. config or value object validations) you may need to call a base method to perform this check. If a field is not set and it is required, an exception is thrown.
